HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH: Alec Baldwin; 
Living Paycheck to Paycheck (All of Them Big)

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
WHEN Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger married in 1993, they did not sign a prenuptial agreement. "My ex-wife was someone I could never imagine getting divorced from," Mr. Baldwin recalled. "My advisers all told me to get a prenup," he said, but "I thought it was forever. We were very naive."
 The couple divorced last year and are now resolving financial and custody disputes. Mr. Baldwin, the square-jawed, handsome actor who can be unusually combative, said this divorce was one battle he could have skipped. 
 Mr. Baldwin's marital problems have convinced him that all engaged couples need prenuptial agreements, especially when they have significant amounts of money that can become the focus of conflict. He has added that rule to others he tries to follow when he considers his finances, he said. 
Though Mr. Baldwin would not be specific, he has accumulated a large amount of money: perhaps $20 million to $23 million, with about $14 million of that in real estate, according to real estate agents and people close to him. 
Mr. Baldwin built such a fortune without ever reaching megastar heights. A well-respected actor, he is still best known for his role in "The Hunt for Red October," the 1990 film. His other film credits include "Malice," "The Edge," with Anthony Hopkins, and "Glengarry Glen Ross." In recent years, he has attracted attention as an outspoken political liberal as well as for several public outbursts. 
The divorce disputes with Ms. Basinger have also received press attention. Mr. Baldwin is convinced that a prenup would have calmed the waters. "Having a prenup is not about segregating assets," Mr. Baldwin said during an interview at his Art Deco-style office on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The office is in the same building where he owns an apartment that is his primary residence. "'It is about: while you and I respect one another, why don't we hammer out this agreement pragmatically," said Mr. Baldwin, dressed in slacks and a white sports shirt. "In divorce the goal is to change partners and dance. A prenup helps people move on."
Without a prenup, Mr. Baldwin may soon pay Ms. Basinger several million dollars, according to people close to him. Still, he appears to be disciplined about holding on to a decent chunk of what he earns.
Mr. Baldwin has a crucial piece of advice for actors: Set aside your money for taxes so you don't make what he calls I.R.S. movies. "You get paid a gross amount; it's up to you to manage your withholding account," he said. Otherwise, he added, "by the fall, you've spent everything you have earned, and you are chasing money to pay the I.R.S." The same principle applies to anyone who is self-employed, he said.
Cash problems can leave performers prey to whatever project comes along. "If the only movie you can get to do is bad, it may be the last movie you make," Mr. Baldwin said. 
He is leery of assuming that the amount of money he makes in a particular year is what he will continue to make. "Actors get on a path where they make $250,000 and then $500,000 and then $1 million and they get seduced into thinking they are going to have that growth," he said. "People start living like they are going to make more money and they don't."
TO handle his own money, Mr. Baldwin talks regularly with Stephen Smith, an accountant who heads his own firm and oversees Mr. Baldwin's financial affairs, including taxes, budgeting and writing checks. Mr. Smith also monitors Mr. Baldwin's various sources of income, including residuals, the amounts paid when older films reach certain revenue goals. 
Occasionally, Mr. Baldwin has picked stocks, but generally with poor results.
"I bought a lot of Global Crossing," he said, because a colleague knew a lot of people who worked for the company, which eventually filed for bankruptcy protection. "All the buys that were based on ideas from friends of mine have not done well," he said.
Mr. Smith discourages investment autonomy for Mr. Baldwin. "If he came to me after Sept. 11 about buying a railroad stock, I would say to him: 'Shut up and go do a voiceover,' " Mr. Smith said. "Creative people should not be picking stocks." 
Fortunately for Mr. Baldwin, his main focus has been New York real estate. He paid about $2.5 million for his two Manhattan apartments in the early 1990's, and they are now valued by a Manhattan real estate agent at about $6.5 million.
He also has a sprawling gray-shingled home on eight acres in Amagansett, N.Y., on Long Island. He paid $1.8 million for the property in 1994 and has invested an additional $3 million in it. It is worth about $8 million to $10 million, according to several real estate agents in the area.
The balance of Mr. Baldwin's money is 60 percent in stocks and 40 percent in bonds (some municipals and some Treasury bills). The money management firm Neuberger Berman oversees the portfolios.
Mr. Baldwin, 45, grew up in a poor family in Massapequa on Long Island. "We always worried about money," he said. He was the second oldest of six siblings, four of whom are actors. His late father, also named Alec, who died in 1983, was a schoolteacher and football coach.
"I am somebody who was woefully concerned about my economic insecurity," Mr. Baldwin said. "I was not in soup lines, but there was the wolf at the door all the time. My parents were fighting about money. The fights were about which bills to pay." 
MR. BALDWIN attended George Washington University in Washington, where he majored in political science, but on a dare from a friend, he auditioned for New York University's drama program and was accepted. In 1981, he landed a role in "The Doctors," the television soap opera. That led to a three-year stint on the prime-time "Knots Landing." A series of film roles brought him to the attention of Paramount Pictures, which cast him in the lead role in Tom Clancy's "Hunt for Red October." 
But his difficult temperament took its toll. He turned down the lead in the Clancy sequel, "Patriot Games," for the lead in the Broadway revival of "A Streetcar Named Desire." Thoughhe wanted the creative challenge, that decision -- just as his career was taking off -- might have hurt him.
"In Hollywood, you have to do 'one for them,' " he said, referring to nonchallenging roles, "and 'one for me,' " he said of more difficult roles. "I was too quick to take the 'one for me,' " he conceded. 
Several associates say he was difficult with studio executives, and sometimes his temper burst into public view. In 1995, Mr. Baldwin punched a celebrity photographer who was trying to take pictures of Ms. Basinger and the couple's newborn daughter. Mr. Baldwin said he had acted in self-defense. He was acquitted by a jury of misdemeanor battery charges in a criminal case, but was ordered to pay the photographer $4,500 in a civil case. 
Still, by 1996, Mr. Baldwin could command millions for a movie. He was paid $7.5 million, for example, for "The Edge." 
Mr. Baldwin remembers being on the road and calling his business manager and saying, "Listen: I've got to get my hands on a fast million," he said. "You chase the money because your lifestyle gets more expansive. You get on the money train. You want money, money, money. You want your house. You want to go to Europe. You want to take care of your parents," he said, referring to his widowed mother. 
In Hollywood, as success escalates, "there comes a time when, if someone is going to pay you $5 million for a movie, you go: 'What, they are going to pay me a lousy $5 million?' " Mr. Baldwin said.
"Then you turn around and if your career devolves a little bit, $1 million or $2 million is looking pretty good," he added. "It's breathtaking, the kind of leaps you can make in a 12-month period."
Mr. Baldwin credits Ron Meyer, a founding partner at the Creative Artists Agency, with much of his financial success. Mr. Meyer represented him from 1991 to 1995. 
"Ron was my agent and that was when I made the most money," Mr. Baldwin said. "He said to me: 'They are not all going to be "The Godfather." You throw spaghetti against the wall and see if it sticks. Just make movies.' " Mr. Meyer is now chairman of Universal Studios.
But Mr. Meyer could not ensure that Mr. Baldwin's films would become hits. When some of them fizzled at the box office and his squabbles grabbed headlines, his reputation suffered. "I don't make as much money as I did five or six years ago," he conceded. 
Today, Mr. Baldwin "dabbles in studio films and makes independent films," as he describes his career. He exhibits a certain contempt for mainstream Hollywood films.
"You hold your nose and do them," he said. "They are like potato chips. They aren't very nutritious." 
He works steadily. "If I want to send the signal that I want to work a lot, I can, and I am doing that now," he said.
He has the lead role in "The Cooler," which opens in November and is produced by Edward R. Pressman Content Film. For that work he could receive at least $650,000, and more depending on the film's success. He just finished playing Juan Trippe, the longtime chief executive of Pan American Airways, in "The Aviator," the Martin Scorsese film about the life of Howard Hughes. He does voiceovers on commercials for companies including Chevrolet, Mutual of Omaha and General Electric. 
But Mr. Baldwin seems somewhat ambivalent about his current earnings level. "I was not willing to do the things to make more money," he said. "But I am taken more seriously as an actor as a result of the things I did and the choices I made. I make less, but I can't complain. I am happy. If I did better, maybe I would be happier. " 
WHENEVER he works, he says, he reads the fine print in his contracts and tries to learn as much as possible about people with whom he does business.
"I don't mean to sound sexist," he said. "But don't be some girl who is dating a leading man on the movie set and they are in bed one day and the leading man says, 'Hey, you ought to go with my business manager.' "
Mr. Baldwin said he had not always been so skillful at judging business associates. Several years ago, he agreed to produce and take a small role in "The Devil and Daniel Webster." He contends that he was never paid the fees he was promised because the producer David Glasser had not raised enough money to complete the film although he indicated that he had. 
"Somebody in that organization knew that he didn't have all the money," Mr. Baldwin said. "We finishing shooting the film, but he did not have the money for post-production." Mr. Baldwin is waiting to see if the movie is distributed before suing for the money he is owed, he said.
Mr. Glasser said that Mr. Baldwin's allegations "are simply untrue."
"He knew that a couple of investors fell out and he knew everything that was happening all along the way," Mr. Glasser added.
FOR his part, Mr. Baldwin is cynical about the industry. "So much of the movie business is this pathetic quasi-friendship thing," he said. "I have had people say: 'I can pay you $500,000 for a movie, but I can't pay it now. I will pay you $350,000 and defer $150,000.' But we are friends and we are partners on this movie. Your cleaner does not walk up to you and say: 'I couldn't get the stains out of the shirt, but we are friends, aren't we?' "
Of course, it is too late for Mr. Baldwin to adhere to another rule, the need for a prenup, and that is likely to cost him, both psychologically and financially. "Divorce is like death," he said. "It is the most debilitating experience of my life," Mr. Baldwin said. 
Mr. Baldwin maintains that he was shocked by the news that his wife wanted to end the marriage. "My wife was my whole world," he said. Neither has remarried.
Lawyers for Mr. Baldwin and Ms. Basinger have been haggling over a financial settlement and custody of the couple's daughter. 
If the arguments over money and custody have been rough, he said, he does not blame his wife. He said he believed that the lawyers aggravated the conflict. "If she said she wanted $10 million, they would say: make it $15 million. Shakespeare was right: kill the lawyers." Ms. Basinger declined to comment. 
But the lawyers are alive and well. Ms. Basinger lives in California, and under California law, the assets earned during a marriage are divided equally. That could mean Mr. Baldwin would have to pay her several million. 
Despite the unpredictability of his income, Mr. Baldwin continues to make charitable contributions. This year he gave $250,000 to the East Hampton Day Care Center.
If his wealth reaches $40 million, he said, he might stop making movies. "I have said to my friends, there are people like Hanks and Cruise," he said, referring to the famous Toms. "They get $20 million a movie. If I got that, I would make two movies and never make another movie as long as I lived.
"There are other things I want to do," he said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; 
Fewer Patrols, More Fear

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR

 BODY:
EVERY fall as the weather turns colder, the Police Department thins the ranks of officers who patrol Prospect Park. But after a daylight attack there two weeks ago that left a 33-year-old woman hospitalized, nearby residents are anxious about this routine seasonal shift and the overall level of park safety.
 On Tuesday, more than 80 people gathered at the park's Picnic House for a sometimes stormy debate with officials over these issues. On Oct. 14, as many of them knew, the number of officers who patrol the park will drop to its regular detail of 11 from its summer detail of 26. 
 That fact was of special interest to residents because the attack earlier this month was thwarted by a passing officer, who arrested a suspect. 
 But the residents' worries about park dangers extended beyond the recent crime. They complained about trash overflow, a dearth of emergency telephones in the park, and camping, drugs and prostitution in the shrubbery. 
 "There are people urinating, defecating, making love," said Martin Haber, who lives near Bartel Pritchard Square, at the westernmost edge of the park. "They're drunk and stoned every day, and I have a 10-year-old and I have to walk her by that every day."
 Susan Kramer, a Park Slope resident, said that a park path near Fifth and Sixth Streets was so overgrown and garbage-strewn that she now avoided it, even when with her Rottweiler. "I used to be able to walk up and down this area without hesitation," she said. 
 Deputy Inspector Edward Mullen of the 78th Precinct said that the police have stepped up efforts to remove people from Bartel Pritchard Square, and that park crime was down this year over last. 
 "The violent attack two weeks ago, that was the only serious assault since I've been here," said Inspector Mullen, who has been at the precinct for two and a half years. The only other assault this year was a groping incident. "But," he added, "one assault is too many." 
 Some people expressed concern that the city's economic woes were undermining security. "Going back 10 years, it had gotten better," said Tim O'Dea, one resident. "But this summer there was an influx of new people who came, drinking, sleeping in the park."
 Still, said Tupper W. Thomas, the park's administrator, "When you consider that there are 7 million visitors a year, two incidents is amazing." 
 TARA BAHRAMPOUR

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN/LITTLE ITALY; 
Hangout for the Courtroom Crowd Succumbs to Economic Laws

BYLINE:  By STEVE KURUTZ

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH legal arguments have long echoed down the austere halls of the Criminal Court building on Centre Street, many spirited lawyerly discussions also occurred a few blocks east, in a dim, shoebox-sized Italian restaurant named Giambone. Now, as workers at Centre Street and other nearby courthouses dig into their fall workload, they are discovering that this neighborhood fixture is gone. 
 Located on a narrow stretch of Mulberry Street two blocks south of Canal, Giambone, a virtual clubhouse for lawyers, judges, cops and defendants with a history as rich as its clam sauce, closed its doors in June. It was a victim of 9/11 and the sluggish economy, which all but eliminated the evening dinner crowd. 
Originally housed in a marble-floored basement, which served it well during Prohibition, the restaurant was opened in 1914 by a strapping fellow named Italo Susi, who went by the nickname Giambone. In 1935, after the upstairs tenant, a Western Union office, left, Italo moved his eatery aboveground and, along with his son Tony, built the place into a bustling, neighborhood joint. 
 Within a stone's throw of various courthouses, Giambone was a natural choice for people who worked at the courthouse or merely visited it from time to time, like the mobster John Gotti. Tony Susi, now 82, still remembers his introduction to the once-Teflon don. 
 "The goons came over and said, 'Would you accept John Gotti?' I said, 'Of course.' Then they said, 'Would you wait on him personally?' So I waited on him. We got along pretty well, too. I spoke to him in Italian." Mr. Gotti ordered the calamari and left a $125 tip. 
 Over the years, other celebrities passed through, including the comedian Pat Cooper, who wanted to kiss Mr. Susi upon tasting his linguini alla Sinatra, a house specialty, and John F. Kennedy Jr., who nursed his wounds at Giambone after failing the bar exam for the second time.
 But the true lure of Giambone remained its homey ambiance. The decor -- rickety tables, taxidermied fish on the wall -- was as unfashionable as your grandfather's basement, and nearly as dusty. The menu was varied but never fancy. And Mr. Susi, by all accounts a gracious host, presided over a cast of regulars that included a fellow named Louie Beans, a struggling lounge singer named Detie Baxter, and Louis Martine, a big, garrulous prankster. 
 Asked about the many stunts he pulled at Giambone, Mr. Martine, a retired lawyer, fondly recalled the sweltering day he sent two colleagues on a goose chase in search of a Chinese tailor rumored to sell cheap suits. "By the time the guys got back, they were walking swimming pools," he said with a laugh. "They were mad as hell."
 There is another reason to mourn Giambone. Except for a half-Italian, half-Chinese place next door, it was the last Italian restaurant on Mulberry Street below Canal.
 Next month the space will reopen as a Chinese furniture store, furthering the Asian dominance of an area that, according to Mr. Susi, once housed seven Italian restaurants. 
 Mr. Susi retired in 1990, selling the restaurant to a man named Joseph Elias. Bob Jenny, a spokesman for NewYork City Management, the owner of the building, said that Mr. Elias informed the company last spring that he was closing the struggling business. Mr. Elias could not be reached for comment. 
 For its many former customers, the bottom line is that the restaurant will be missed. "It's left a hole in the neighborhood,"' said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney and a longtime regular. "Now, we go to Odeon or Forlini's."
 STEVE KURUTZ

HEADLINE: The Nation: Golden Rules; 
As California Goes, So Goes the Country?

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
MORE than 60 years ago, the columnist Westbrook Pegler, noting California's penchant for political experimentation and social turmoil, proposed that a guardian should be appointed and the state declared incompetent to manage its own affairs. Last week, California's recall election drama led the columnist George F. Will to call it "the sick man of the Republic."
 It has always been easy for the rest of the country to bash California, and to dismiss its self-conscious Left Coast exceptionalism as just that. In fact, California has a state constitution and a long cultural tradition that allow for an unusual degree of political volatility, through citizen referendums, ballot initiatives and, yes, electoral recall. 
 But the plain truth is that the same germs that have made California the Fabulous Invalid of national politics -- a sluggish economy, high unemployment, budget shortfalls, a shaky electrical grid and an abiding distrust in politicians' ability to do much of anything about such problems -- are pulsing through the bloodstream of American democracy more broadly.
Anyone who thought the 2000 presidential recount was a once-in-a-lifetime experience may well have been wrong, as the courts re-enacted the topsy-turvy election last week. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth District in San Francisco announced that it would reconsider the decision of its three-judge panel to postpone the California recall on the grounds that the planned Oct. 7 balloting did not give several counties with large minority populations enough time to replace punch-card voting machines of the type that wrought havoc in Florida. 
"You can make the usual jokes about the colorful candidates and so on," said Kevin Starr, a history professor at the University of Southern California and author of a multi-volume social history of the state. "But if one probes deeper, and says, 'Are state governments becoming increasingly out of sync with the governed,' then you could look at the situation in California as yet another instance in which California gets there first, because it's larger, less disciplined, less tradition-minded, and the function that it so often seems to fill in national life is of acting out things."
At a minimum, the California mess, in which the experienced but hugely unpopular Democratic governor, Gray Davis, faces recall just a year after Republicans nearly defeated him with a novice candidate, suggests the degree to which Americans are now willing to regard every election -- and every political decision -- as contestable. Electoral and political procedures devised in the 18th century to produce a clockwork of checks and balances fare less well in the white-hot, 24-hours-a-day, seven-days-week glare of the 21st century.
In Texas, where Republicans swept to power in the State Legislature last year for the first time in a century, Democratic lawmakers fled twice to neighboring states this year in an effort to thwart passage of a Republican-drawn Congressional redistricting plan that would replace the one imposed by a court when the Democratic-controlled legislature failed to act after the 2000 census. In Nevada, the Republican governor, Kenny Guinn, is facing a nascent recall movement over his support for raising taxes. 
"There is a national dissatisfaction," said Curtis B. Gans, the director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate in Washington. "I see it most clearly in things like registration figures, in which over the last 30 years, Democratic Party registration has declined from the mid-40's of the eligible electorate down to the low 30's, and Republican registration has increased in the South but declined elsewhere. The electorate is very deeply and partisanly polarized, and there is a dissatisfaction with this type of politics, which yields very little but inaction on a whole series of relevant issues."
There is reason to doubt the extent of California's power as a trendsetter. Proposition 13, which capped property taxes in 1978, helped inspire similar tax-cutting measures in more than 40 states, but few so radical. Proposition 209, which banned the use of racial preferences in college admissions, state employment and contracting in 1996, tapped into widespread anti-affirmative action sentiment but hardly inspired a nationwide movement.
And certainly, some circumstances paving the way for the recall are peculiar to California, including the state's increasing reliance, since Proposition 13, on a raft of ballot initiatives. Voters, increasingly frustrated at their elected representatives' unwillingness to tackle what they see as tough problems, have passed measures that make it just that much harder for politicians to tackle tough problems.
And voters are specifically angry at the administration of Gray Davis. "I think Gray Davis is the issue there," said Michael K. Deaver, the former aide to Ronald Reagan. On the issues Californians are angry about -- illegal immigration, power failures and budget deficits -- "Gray Davis symbolizes all that," he said.
But in many ways, California looks like the country, if in the extreme. By its sheer size, California carries special weight. "If the Pilgrims had landed in Santa Monica Bay, there'd be something like 13 states in California," Dr. Starr said.
And Californians -- like the rest of the country, only maybe a little bit more so -- want it all, all the time: lower taxes and smaller classrooms; tighter pollution controls and bigger S.U.V.'s; cheap labor and fresh produce but tighter limits on immigration and provision of social services. Under Republican and Democratic governors alike over the past 50 years, they have grown used to getting such bounty, especially during the dot-com boom of the late 1990's. Now, the state budget faces a steadily growing deficit that Republicans accused Mr. Davis of failing to acknowledge as he campaigned. Mr. Davis won re-election by just five percentage points last fall, in an election that drew just over 35 percent of eligible voters -- the lowest turnout ever in a California general election. 
But with its particularly broad powers of referendum, California provides the rest of the country with examples of what can happen when voters get their way, unfiltered by politicians or legislators.
"Voters aren't provided real choices," said Alan Ehrenhalt, the executive editor of Governing magazine. "They are asked, would you like ice cream one year, and then the next year, would you like cake? It doesn't ask of voters to make responsible choices from limited alternatives."
D. J. Waldie, the author of "Holy Land, A Suburban Memoir," put it another way. "The initiative, as it's practiced, is the heroin of democracy." 
Lou Cannon, the California journalist and biographer of Ronald Reagan, sees at least some rays of hope in the recall, even though he opposes it. It has sparked new voter registration and led California's local television stations -- famously inattentive to politics for years -- to explore issues like the state budget with sudden vigor. And in that way, Mr. Cannon suggests, the state might be fixing a national ill: apathy and distrust of the political process.
"To me, the great threat to American democracy is not Howard Dean or the religious right," Mr. Cannon said. "It's that more and more people are opting out of it."

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Stocks Rise Along With Company Earnings

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stocks climbed again last week, as the market's rally moved into its seventh month. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average has risen in 21 of the last 28 weeks. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has been in the black for 20 out of 28 weeks, while the Nasdaq composite has climbed in 19 of the 28. 
 Corporate earnings have been improving. More investors appear to believe that Federal Reserve policy makers, who left their benchmark interest rate at 1 percent after their meeting last week, will keep rates low well into next year.
 The S.& P.'s telecom sector index has surged 46 percent since the 2003 market low on March 11. The consumer discretionary sector has also jumped 38 percent.
 For the week, the Nasdaq climbed 50.67 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,905.70. The Dow was up 173.27, or 1.8 percent, to 9,644.82, while the S.& P. 500 index rose 17.67 points, or 1.73 percent, to 1,036.30.
 Prices of Treasury notes and bonds climbed, and yields, which move in the opposite direction, fell. The yield on the 10-year note declined to 4.17 percent from 4.25 percent a week earlier. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: Mismatched Conditions In the U.S. Economy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Good Economy. Bad Job Market. Huh?" (Economic View, Sept. 14) suggested that technological improvements, as well as employers' squeezing more work from existing workers, are possible root causes of the current economic phenomenon of increasing productivity and declining demand. 
 But the most important cause is the rapid "offshoring" of large numbers of skilled and service jobs like those in programming, telephone customer service and accounting. These jobs have joined the manufacturing positions already lost to countries where companies can hire such labor for a small fraction of what American workers would be paid. This directly increases productivity, which is measured as output per dollar spent on labor.
While offshoring dramatically decreases corporate costs, it also eliminates the domestic salaries that provide the greatest demand for these companies' products. Unfortunately, this makes less realistic the idea that increased demand will come from companies' profit-taking shareholders.

JASON KNAPP
Solana Beach, Calif., Sept. 14

The writer is senior vice president of the Strategic Data Corporation, a software company in Santa Monica, Calif.

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Finding Freedom In the Corporate Life

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA R. OLSEN

 BODY:
DURING the spring, J. Robert Carr was running a boutique law firm specializing in employment and labor law when he was offered a senior position at a trade association. His law practice was satisfying, he said, but the offer was just too good to pass up. So, in May, he became a vice president of the association, the Society for Human Resource Management. 
 At a time when tens of thousands of workers are starting out on their own, some seasoned entrepreneurs are finding that the independent life, while rewarding, can be too difficult. Whether it is the limited support staff, the rising cost of employee benefits or the difficulty of getting work from cost-cutting companies, life for some entrepreneurs -- or lawyers or doctors in private practice -- is more stressful than it has been in years. As a result, some are deciding that the corporate world looks more appealing. 
 John Gramer, director of the New York branch of Spherion Professional Recruiting, says corporate positions can offer greater income and job security than entrepreneurial jobs, in which the loss of a client or two can have a crippling effect. It is not uncommon, he said, for managers who went out on their own after the job cuts following the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to be returning to the corporate world now that some companies seem to be hiring again.
 Many executive clients of Deborah Brown-Volkman, a career coach in Long Beach, N.Y., find corporate jobs more rewarding than self-employment, she said. "Taking a corporate position can actually give managers more freedom," Ms. Brown-Volkman said. "Before, they had less control because they were handling problems all day. Now they can make plans for their departments and implement them with fewer distractions."
 Executives returning to corporate life are also looking for more free time, she said. "Business owners have very little of it," she added.
 Mr. Carr started his law practice in January 2002 after leaving AARP, the retirees' lobbying group, where he was the director of human resources. But when the opportunity for his new job, at the trade association, came along in May, he decided that it would allow him to make more of a difference.
 His current position, he said, "gives him the leverage to impact a couple hundred thousand human resource professionals trying to affect other people's lives."
 "I can focus on my expertise in a way that running my own practice, where I had to be a jack of all trades, did not allow me to," he added.
 Some entrepreneurs and independent professionals are considering corporate jobs because the continuing weakness in the economy makes their independent livelihood more precarious. Michael Russell was senior director of investor relations for the VTEL Corporation, a videoconferencing company in Austin, Tex., from 1998 to 2001. When VTEL reorganized in May 2001, he left to start his own investor relations firm, the StreetSmart Company. 
 Within a year, however, he said he felt limited by the scale of his firm, and was unsure what the impending recession might mean for its future. When Pierpont Communications, a public relations firm in Austin, approached him with the offer of an executive position, he had to make a decision. "I had just struck the mother lode and landed a lucrative contract in the insurance industry," Mr. Russell said, but he decided to join Pierpont and take his clients with him.
 Tom Thomasson of Atlanta has lived through other problems that arise in small entrepreneurial ventures. Mr. Thomasson spent 20 years in the health care industry, rising to director of sales for MAG Mutual Insurance Company in Atlanta. "I think everyone who's been in industry long enough wants to try their hand at having their own business, realizing their own dream," he said. "I saw a whole new niche in the market to fulfill."
 In 1999, he left to start his own health care insurance agency, the Landers & Creel Southeastern Group, with a partner. But the working relationship deteriorated, and the two men are now in a legal dispute over their original contract. In addition, Mr. Thomasson decided that his business model was not producing cash flow when he needed it.
 In July, he accepted a position as director of admissions at the OmniTech Institute, a technology and medical vocational school in Atlanta.
 DESPITE the pitfalls of entrepreneurial work, many executives can thrive on the challenges. But even they sometimes tire of the grueling schedule. For Mark Scott, 56, now a lawyer at Callahan, McCune & Willis in San Francisco, running his own law firm when his children were growing up provided flexibility he would not have had in a large law firm, he said.
 He could take cases in Hawaii that lasted almost a summer and bring his son and daughter with him, and he could usually schedule depositions around his children's lives as well.
 "It was a wonderful way of life," he said. "Once I brought my children to Manhattan when I worked on a six-week case involving a large securities firm, and my 3-year-old daughter learned how to hail a cab," he said. His wife went on the trips, too, he said, and they found baby sitters at the hotels where they stayed.
 By the time his children were grown, however, the sole proprietorship had served its purpose, he said. He sought the benefits a large law firm could offer, like support from otherlawyers on cases. "Once I hit 50, the amount of flying I was doing was grueling, too," he said. Two years ago, he joined Callahan, McCune & Willis. 
 More than half the workers who responded to a recent survey sponsored by Spherion said that they would like to change jobs. Roughly the same number said they were confident that they could earn a living "outside the conventional work structure." But a number of managers who have been self-employed give their new positions in the corporate structure positive marks. 
 Mr. Carr, of the Society for Human Resource Management, said, "even if you're asked to do the work of three people in the corporate world these days, when you're self-employed you might be doing the work of five." He said of his previous job: "I was only chief executive 5 or 10 percent of the time. Many days I was the mail clerk, the graphics artist and the reprographics department."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
As Interest Rates Climb, Must Bank Stocks Fall?

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
BANK shares have been among the most resilient investments of the last three years. But because of the sudden rebound in long-term interest rates, many analysts are warning that the sector risks succumbing to history as well as gravity.
 For decades, returns on bank stocks have correlated strongly with yields on government bonds; as yields rise, bank shares fall, and vice versa. After dropping in June to their lowest levels in years, bond yields staged an energetic reversal, surging by more than one percentage point over two months. 
 The move came as American and European bank shares traded near multiyear highs, relative to the overall stock market. That represented a major shift from their valuations in the summer of 2000, near the top of the dot-com boom At the time, American bank shares lagged so much that a representative portfolio bought at the start of 1982 would have been worth nearly 60 percent less than the same amount invested in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morgan Stanley. Banks closed the gap to about 10 percent last year, but it has since widened to about 20 percent. European banks have performed similarly in recent years. 
 If the historical pattern holds, bank stocks should be acutely vulnerable to the climb in yields. But while the stocks have pulled back, the decline has not been severe. Many analysts, waiting for the other shoe to drop, are encouraging shareholders to sell.
 "The biggest correlation for the performance of banks in the long term is the direction of the bond market," said Richard Davidson, European equity strategist for Morgan Stanley in London, in a note to clients. "Major turns in the bond market have preceded turns in banks' relative performance by one to three months, and the bond market made a significant turn, as we've seen, in mid-June. Our view is that yields will move higher over the next 12 months and that sentiment will move towards short-rate hikes by year-end, both negative developments for banks."
 The American model stock portfolio, or list of recommended stocks, from Morgan Stanley is lightly invested in banks and other financial services companies: 17 percent versus a 20.5 percent weighting for the sector in the S. &P. 500. The model portfolio for Europe allocates 16.1 percent to financial services, versus its 21.1 percent weighting in the market. 
 Professional investors have come to agree with Mr. Davidson. European fund managers polled by Merrill Lynch in early August were heavily invested in banks, but they cut their exposure substantially over the next month to a slight underweighting. In the survey in early August, American managers were extremely light in banks, and they became even more so during the next month.
 American financial stocks are especially vulnerable to rising yields on American government bonds and lag behind their foreign peers when yields rise, said David Bowers, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch in London. He said in a report to clients that global equity managers interested in taking a big bet on economic recovery and rising bond yields "might consider selling U.S. financial stocks."
 Bond yields relate to bank stocks in several ways. Rising yields reflect economic optimism. When investors are in such a mood, they often sell stocks in defensive industries like banks and put the money to work in industries like energy and airlines thatare likely to benefit most from economic recovery.
 There is also a more direct impact. Typically, as long-term interest rates rise, including rates on bank loans, new lending shrinks and the value of a bank's existing loan book falls.
 "When bond yields rise, future loan activity will slow down," Teun Draaisma, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley in London, said in an interview. "At the moment, that impact can be huge."
 Mr. Draaisma and others pointed out, though, that there are banks and then there are banks. Some institutions, including specialists in investment banking, asset management and credit card issuance, suffer few direct effects from rising interest rates and can benefit from a pickup in economic activity. Banks that engage heavily in commercial and mortgage lending are hurt the most, while diversified banks, including the industry giants, fall somewhere in between.
 American banks could be two-time losers from rising bond yields. Many economists say the United States has the brightest prospects for recovery among the major world regions, making cyclical stocks particularly appealing. And American banks have done comparatively more mortgage lending, especially refinancing, so they are suffering from a more acute decline in new lending.
 "Mortgage refinancing is clearly more of an issue in the United States," said David Miller, head of asset allocation at J.P. Morgan Private Bank in London. "Banks are being hurt by the falloff caused by higher rates, and this is clearly a factor in their performance."
 But even for big lenders, he said, rising rates can produce benefits as well, particularly by enhancing their ability to take advantage of spreads in interest rates between financial instruments of different maturities. "Rising yields provide a headwind for the banking sector but also a tailwind," Mr. Miller said. "If we have a steepening of the yield curve, with 10-year bonds rising and short-term rates staying the same because central banks are keeping those rates down, it allows banks to borrow short and lend long." He added that "banks are also beneficiaries of better economic growth," because bad debts shrink.
 Mr. Miller said he thinks European bank stocks may have already fallen enough to reflect the weakening bond market. Simon Melluish, head of United States equities for Gartmore Global Investments in Conshohocken, Pa., made the same argument for American bank stocks, but he suggested that the bond market's condition might not be as poor as others suppose.
 He is betting that most of the selling is over, both in bonds and bank stocks. "We do not expect interest rates to rise very rapidly because we do not see the economy rising at 6 percent to 7 percent in 2004," he said of the American economy. "The bond markets probably overshot on the way down, and we have seen them snap back. The bond market was spelling out economic Armageddon. We never felt that was going to happen."
 Mr. Melluish said that Gartmore has been underweight in American banks, in line with its assumption earlier this year -- a wrong one, as it turned out -- that spreads between long-term and short-term interest rates would narrow. But in a reflection of his sanguine outlook for long-term rates, the stocks Gartmore owns tend to be most heavily leveraged to bond yields and mortgage activity, including Washington Mutual and Bank of America. Gartmore also holds Citigroup and J.P. Morgan Chase, and smaller banks like North Fork, on Long Island. 
 Simon Moss, another Gartmore fund manager, said that most of the picks, big and small, sharedcertain virtues, including managements that execute corporate strategies effectively and keep costs down. Mr. Moss described Citigroup as "one of our core holdings, with a particularly good mixture of businesses, including investment banking, which makes it more of a geared play than straightforward banks," meaning that it can better take advantage of a revival in investment markets.
 As for North Fork, he said, "over time, it has proven itself to have executed well, it has continued to open branches in New Jersey and New York, and it has very good control of costs."
 "We're looking for a pickup in loan demand and think they'll do very well," he added.
 J.P. Morgan Chase is unlike Gartmore's other choices, he said. "It's more a recovery play after management got battered on Latin American loans and venture capital," he said. The bank also lost favor with investors when its large exposure to Enron was disclosed.
 "There is a question mark over its management, compared to Citigroup," Mr. Moss said. "But the stock has fallen so much that we felt the risk of further upsets was all discounted in the price."
 CITIGROUP is also a part of Morgan Stanley's American model portfolio, as is J.P. Morgan Chase, Fifth Third Bancorp and Merrill Lynch. Its European portfolio includes Allied Irish; HSBC and Lloyds TSB in Britain; BNP Paribas in France; Credit Suisse in Switzerland; and IntesaBci in Italy.
 Citigroup Smith Barney, Citigroup's American research arm, compiles a global model portfolio, which includes Bank of America and Wells Fargo among its favored American banks and Royal Bank of Scotland and UniCredito Italiano in Europe. It makes a distinction between banks, which are underrepresented in the portfolio, and "diversified financials," which it overweights. Choices in that category include J.P. Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and UBS of Switzerland.
 Mr. Miller's European portfolios are heavily invested in banks. He prefers British ones like Royal Bank of Scotland, HBOS and Barclays. On the Continent, he said, his choices are "the usual suspects that are still the powerhouses of the industry," including Deutsche Bank in Germany and Credit Suisse. 
 "European banks have come through the current cycle in good shape because they are better managed this time around than in past cycles," he said. "They are in a position to benefit from economic recovery rather than just repair their balance sheets. We think the good news outweighs the bad news."
 Mr. Draaisma, at Morgan Stanley, plugs in the same facts but derives the opposite conclusion. Banks, he suggested, could be victims of their own recent success. Surviving the sluggish economy with their earnings and assets in such good shape, he said, means that there is less room for growth.
 "During recessions, banks have earnings recessions," he said. "That's why they're so leveraged in an economic recovery. Banks' earnings rise massively. But not this time around. That leverage isn't there anymore. There has been 20 fantastic years where loans and earnings growth have been high. Now the market will grow more than the banks, so banks will underperform."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: David L. King; 
Putnam New Value Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
DAVID L. KING, lead manager of the $1.2 billion Putnam New Value fund, describes his style as "earnings power investing" -- finding companies that are cheap based on his estimates of their future earnings power.
 Bargain prices aren't enough. "Besides a depressed stock price," Mr. King said from his office in Boston, "we look for reasons for future stock price increases." These can be catalysts like cyclical industry changes, new products or markets, or changes in management. 
 The fund returned 1.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years through August, adjusted for its maximum load, or sales charge, of 5.75 percent. Its peer group of funds that buy large value stocks lost 3.3 percent, annualized, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 11.4 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.
 The fund returned 7.7 percent in the 12 months through August, adjusted for the load, compared with 7.8 percent for its group and 12.1 percent for the index.
 Mr. King, 46, is managing director of Putnam Investment Management, the fund's investment adviser; his co-manager is Michael J. Abata, 35, senior vice president of the adviser. The average market capitalization of the portfolio companies is $26.4 billion, versus $18.8 billion for the S.&P. 500.
 In choosing stocks, Mr. King looks at market cap as a combination of factors, including "the real size of the business plus people's impressions of the business." Typically, he picks the fund's roughly 70 stocks from companies that have been in business for at least a decade and have generated at least $1 billion in revenue during the last 12 months. He identifies the cheapest half of that universe based primarily on ratios of price to cash flow and price to earnings.
 Next, he ranks the companies by various factors, including earnings quality. A company with poor earnings quality, he said, would be one that reports strong earnings but low cash flow because of high depreciation or other accounting differences.
 He also looks at what he calls indications of "signaling" -- generally insider buying and short-selling. And he examines a company's price-to-earnings ratio, adjusted for its expected growth rate.
 Another factor is the company's estimated fair value, based on its discounted cash flow and prepared with the help of about 50 global equity research analysts.
 Mr. King then looks at the top 40 percent of companies on his resulting list and searches for catalysts that might reverse a company's stock price decline. "Often, in really down-and-out companies that may have no earnings," he said, "we can pick up clues about the company's future in its balance sheet." Those include improvements in liquidity or upgrades in credit ratings.
 He aims to hold shares about two to five years, on average, and he sells a stock when it approaches what he considers fair value.
 In June, Mr. King began buying shares of the Chubb Corporation, the insurer based in Warren, N.J. Property and casualty insurance premiums have risen after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, he said, adding, "Chubb has been a bit of a laggard during the positive insurance cycle."
 He expects Chubb to catch up, partly because the chief executive, John D. Finnegan, who came from GMAC late last year, "is not a traditional insurance guy" and "takes more of a financial services view."
 Chubb's high-end business in homeowners' insurance is also appealing, Mr. King said. He paid $60.14, on average, for the entire position; the stock now trades at $64.66. 
 MR. KING began buying shares of Dow Chemical in October 2002 and paid $30.51, on average; they now trade at $33.55. He called Dow "the premier commercial chemical company in the world but highly cyclical." 
 Industry conditions are near bottom because of the global economic slowdown, he said, and should improve as the North American and European economies rebound. Moreover, Dow recently brought back its former chief executive, William Stavropoulos, "giving us confidence in management," he said.
 Another holding, Southern Union, based in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., is primarily a natural-gas distributor. Mr. King called it "a cheap stock that's pretty boring" but said the company had been overlooked because, unlike most utilities, it pays no dividend. Besides benefiting from high natural-gas prices, he said, Southern Union will profit from its acquisition this year of Panhandle Eastern, which broadens its business.
 "I think this will be a transforming acquisition," he said, "raising the company's profile and earnings power." 
 He began buying shares in July, paying $15.31, on average; they are now at $17.79.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Uncertainty Inside Emergency Rooms

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A MIDDLE-AGED woman arrived at the Antelope Valley Hospital in Lancaster, Calif., this summer with a large abscess in her neck. Dr. Lawrence Stock, an emergency-room physician on duty, ordered a CAT scan and antibiotics, but the woman needed a head-and-neck surgeon to drain the abscess. Antelope Valley doesn't have such a surgeon on call, so Dr. Stock transferred the patient to a hospital that does. 
 Two days later, the woman, who lacked insurance, ended up back at Antelope Valley. Dr. Stock said she told him that after spending two days on a gurney virtually untreated at the second hospital, in Los Angeles, about 100 miles away, she decided to come home. The head-and-neck staff surgeon at Antelope Valley then operated on the woman, even though the hospital did not have an on-call arrangement with him. 
 "You'd think a hospital of our size would have specialist backup 24/7," Dr. Stock said. "But sometimes we have to transfer patients 10 times a day." The problem, he said, is likely to become worse. "We're living the future here," Dr. Stock said.
 It's a future that may leave us longing for the good old days. In 1986, the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act -- often called the "patient anti-dumping statute" -- was passed to prevent hospitals from refusing to treat patients or from transferring them based on ability to pay. Emergency rooms became a safe harbor, where anyone could go for care anytime. 
 But budget problems and other financial issues have forced more than 500 hospital emergency departments to close since 1990, according to the American Hospital Association. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta estimates that emergency-room patient visits rose about 20 percent from 1992 to 2001. 
 Two out of every three hospitals sometimes reroute ambulances away from their emergency departments because of overcrowding, according to the General Accounting Office. Many specialists, meanwhile, unhappy with low payment rates for treating poor and uninsured patients, have left hospital staff jobs for specialty clinics or private practice, where call duty isn't required.
 Now emergency care may be further compromised by a new regulation, effective Nov. 10, that eases requirements for on-call specialty coverage. The regulation, from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, gives hospitals discretion, based on patient needs, the hospitals' capabilities and the availability of on-call physicians, to provide on-call coverage as they see fit.
 "The rule will provide hospitals flexibility in how they organize their coverage," said Maureen Mudron, counsel for the American Hospital Association.
 But emergency-department physicians are worried that there will be many more scenes like the one in Antelope Valley. "There will be a lot more patients, especially indigent patients, falling through the cracks," said Dr. Loren Johnson, chief medical officer of Sutter Emergency Medical Associates, a group of 50 full-time emergency physicians in Sacramento.
 Not only indigent patients will be affected by the new regulation. From 1996 to 2001, emergency-room visits by people with private insurance jumped 24 percent, accounting for a majority of the overall increase in visits those years, according to a report scheduled for release this fall by the Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonprofit research group in Washington.
 "People are reporting they're having trouble getting in to see their regular doctors," said Peter J. Cunningham, a senior researcher at the center and a co-author of the report. "The emergency department becomes the place they go when they can't get an appointment."
 Jesse Perrin, 31, a software engineer, said he ended up in the emergency department at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan one morning in July, after suffering severe dizziness. Mr. Perrin, who had just joined an Aetna plan,said that he had called doctors but that they would not see him because he had not yet chosen a primary care physician. "It wasn't a dire emergency, but I did feel I wanted to see a doctor that day," he said. 
 He was fortunate: he said he waited just 15 minutes before being taken in for tests and a consultation with a neurologist at the emergency room. 
 Many aren't so lucky. When Arthur Ulrich, 79, hurt his leg picking beans a few weeks ago in his garden in East Alton, Ill., near St. Louis, his doctor sent him to the emergency department at Barnes-Jewish Hospital in St. Louis to see a specialist in vascular surgery. Mr. Ulrich said his leg was painfully swollen and black and blue from groin to ankle. He said he waited five hours to be seen by the main specialist and have tests performed. By then, he said, "my leg was hurting so bad I was crying." Mr. Ulrich said he waited an additional three hours or so before X-rays were taken. The diagnosis was a blood clot in his thigh muscle, for which the treatment was rest and a bandage. 
 Sharon O'Keefe, the hospital's chief operating officer, said that she could not comment on the specifics of Mr. Ulrich's care, but said that during the several hours he was at the hospital, he received extensive lab and radiologic tests and was seen by at least three specialists. Such an extensive work-up, she said, takes time to arrange and to perform.
 THERE is no easy fix, but one thing the system clearly needs is money. The 1986 law requires that hospitals and doctors provide emergency care to everyone, though it doesn't provide the means to do so. It's an unfunded mandate. 
 In an American Medical Association study, emergency physicians, on average, reported $138,300 of uncollectable payments for providing care under the law in 2000. 
 If the Bush administration is serious about improving emergency services, it should look for ways to give the system a financial shot in the arm, instead of tinkering with on-call specialist requirements.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Prospecting For Nuggets In Tobacco Stocks

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
TOBACCO companies have many reasons to feel besieged. The number of smokers hasn't changed much since 1990, but shipment volumes are sliding. Tax increases have pushed prices up at a much faster rate than inflation. Deep discount brands are taking a big piece of the market. And operating profits are falling, in some cases precipitously. Last week, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco said it would lay off 40 percent of its work force to cut $1 billion in costs over the next two years. 
 Martin Feldman, a tobacco industry analyst at Merrill Lynch, talked about the business last week. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. How much have volumes shrunk in the past few years?

A. Last year, the industry shipped 391 billion cigarettes in the United States. In 1998 that figure was 461 billion. This year, I estimate that shipments will be 372 billion. And for the foreseeable future, industry volumes are likely to decline by 2 percent to 3 percent annually.
 Combined with falling volumes, in the last five years there has been significant growth in the deep-discount segment of the market. In 1997, they represented about 1.5 percent of sales. At present, I estimate that deep-discount brands represent about 13 percent of the overall market.

Q. Why are deep discounters taking so much market share?

A. In November 1998, the Big Four manufacturers settled claims the 50 individual states had against the industry. As a result, the cost per pack to each of those producers was raised by about 50 cents. For a very small proportion of their volumes, little manufacturers are exempted in perpetuity from that cost. On the majority on which they do make payments, those payments are about 15 cents less per pack than big manufacturers.
 They have also benefited from the fact that since 1998 the big manufacturers, led by Philip Morris USA, raised prices particularly aggressively to try to compensate for the settlement with the states. 
 Finally, the economy has been weakening since early in 2000, and that has hurt smokers, whose average household income is $35,000. Consumers who are economically challenged but who smoke have no choice but to trade down. 
 At present, I estimate the average price per pack of the legal discount brands is about $1.95. That is a huge difference from the average price of $3.40 for Camel or Marlboro.

Q. What did you make of the announcement from RJR about layoffs?

A. The problem with RJR is that while it is doing an admirable job in trying to control its costs, of its four big brands it is having success with just one, Camel. And I think that with cuts of this size it will be a challenge for the company to maintain its relationships with wholesalers, retailers and smokers while continuing to produce a high-quality product.

Q. How serious are the companies' legal problems?

A. The single most important determinant of tobacco company valuations is the litigation environment. And while some serious challenges remain, the risk from litigation is materially less today than it was five years ago. In short, even though profitability has deteriorated substantially, there is still significant room for multiple expansion and an increase in returns to shareholders if the litigation environment continues to improve.

Q. What legal hurdles remain?

A. In the late 1990's, there were six types of claims against the industry. Today, there are only two cases of major importance: the class-action suit in Illinois, which is ongoing, and the Justice Department's lawsuit, where only one claim remains intact.
 I would expect both cases to be resolved over the next 12 to 36 months.

Q. What can investors expect for the companies if these legal problems, and their corresponding potential liabilities go away?

A. I think you will see the companies grow returns to shareholders in the form of increased dividends and buyback programs. And, in the case of Altria, you may see a significant corporate restructuring. I would expect the company will completely spin off its Kraft food unit, forcing the market to put a real valuation on the tobacco business.

Q. Given your outlook, which of these stocks do you like?

A. The potential restructuring of Altria makes it the most interesting company to own over the next 36 months.
 British American Tobacco is also attractive because of its significant exposure to the third world, where there is still margin expansion, consumers are trading up to more expensive brands, excise taxes are still low, and industry volumes in many markets are still rising. 
 From a purely fundamental perspective, I like BAT. But for pure capital appreciation over the next three years, I think Altria is the stock to own.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Martin Feldman 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Interview

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Counting the Ways to Count Corporate Earnings

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
CORPORATE earnings are expected to rise 17 percent this year. Earnings are also considered likely to surge 61 percent for 2003. Another forecast puts the gain at 78 percent. 
 All these forecasts were provided by the same firm, Standard & Poor's, for the same stock index, the S.&P. 500. 
 Earnings reports and forecasts have often been confusing -- and misleading. Companies have been known to manipulate the numbers to enhance their performance and their prospects. So analysts at firms like S.&P. have come up with a variety of filters for corporate earnings. But sometimes they seem to make the picture murkier. 
 "It is difficult for the professional to figure it out," lamented Jim Floyd, senior analyst at the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis. Still, Mr. Floyd says that after sorting the various earnings forecasts, he has concluded that the earnings outlook this year has really improved substantially.
 But first, let's make some sense of those numbers.
 S.&P.'s forecast of a 17 percent increase this year is based on a measure known as operating earnings. Most companies and many Wall Street analysts use this figure because it allows companies to put their best foot forward. Operating earnings exclude so-called one-time write-offs and other special charges that can reduce earnings. Those who use them say operating earnings give a clearer -- and smoother -- picture of earnings over time.
 For this reason, operating earnings suffered the least after the market crash, the recession and the sluggish growth that has followed. Twelve-month operating earnings for the S.&P. 500 index fell 31.6 percent from the third quarter of 2000 through the fourth quarter of 2001.
 By contrast, the second S.&P. earnings measure, reported earnings, plunged 54 percent in the same period. S.&P. says that reported earnings are expected to rise 61 percent this year. Reported earnings follow generally accepted accounting practices, or GAAP, and therefore are more volatile because one-time events are not excluded.
 The newest S.&P. yardstick is called core earnings, which are forecast to rise 78 percent this year. This measure is designed to account for the cost of stock options, which became a popular form of compensation during the technology boom. Companies have excluded stock options from the group of expenses that would reduce earnings; the core earnings measure restores them. Core earnings also remove another accounting gimmick that inflates corporate earnings. When bond and stock market returns on a pension fund's investments exceed the expected return, a company can add the excess return to earnings. Core earnings exclude this add-on. 
 Despite the wide disparity among these three earnings forecasts, actual earnings performance this year provides a positive underpinning for this year's stock market rally, during which the S.&P. 500 has climbed 17.8 percent. And while it may further confuse matters, a fourth, much broader, measure of corporate profits, based on the gross domestic product, is also giving good signals. Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at ITG/Hoenig, is predicting that G.D.P. corporate profits will rise 25 percent this year. 
 In an effort to make sense of all of these forecasts, Mr. Floyd of the Leuthold Group has complicated the picture even further. He ignores core earnings because they are too new to have a good historical context. Because both reported and operating earnings can be off the mark, Mr. Floyd likes to average the two. Then he averages this adjusted earnings number for five years, using the numbers for the previous four years as well as the forecast for the next year to smooth the impact of the economic cycle. In the end, Mr. Floyd said he came up with a forecast of an increase of 5.1 percent this year, a tiny amount compared with all of the S.&P. calculations.
 But he has tortured the numbers enough that this confession of only modest earnings growth gives him reason to be positive about the stock market.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
More Bumps in the Road to Retirement

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
What a difference five years makes. In 1998, a Merrill Lynch survey showed that 90 percent of Americans felt that they were cruising toward retirement, many even envisioning it by 62. 
 Then the economy hit a few nasty bumps, smashing those golf-filled dreams. In Merrill's latest survey, just 47 percent feel that they have saved enough, with a third now expecting to labor past 65. And 15 percent don't bother to save at all -- mainly people in the lower brackets, but even some with high incomes, too. 
 In fact, many Americans are going deeper in debt, and of those who seek relief in "debt management" plans, those nearing retirement are in the biggest hole. In this group, women over 50 owe half their income, men nearly two-thirds. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: With a Big Victory, Japanese Premier Gains Momentum 

BYLINE:  By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was re-elected leader of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party today in a decisive victory that could give him renewed momentum to push through reforms in the world's second largest economy and to keep nudging the country toward a more muscular role internationally.
 Buoyed by his personal popularity, Mr. Koizumi was chosen in the first round by party lawmakers and members, many of whom disagree with his reformist policies but need him as a standard-bearer in general elections. The prime minister, who won with more than 60 percent of the votes against three other challengers, said he would reshuffle his cabinet on Monday. 
 With the party's grip on Parliament, the victory almost certainly means Mr. Koizumi will win a second term as prime minister, in a general election likely to be held in November. Today's victory by Mr. Koizumi, 61, comes at a pivotal point for Japan, both domestically and internationally.
Mr. Koizumi has pledged to press ahead with the economic and political reforms undertaken since he became prime minister in April 2001. The reforms have met strong resistance from conservative members of his own party, including the three who ran against him.
"This election for party leader was an election for the L.D.P. to truly become the party of the people and the party of reform," Mr. Koizumi said in a short speech at the party's headquarters here.
At a news conference later, he pledged to "move ahead with the structural reforms that have been tackled thus far to revitalize the economy."
Under Mr. Koizumi, who has supported the Bush administration's war in Iraq and has sought to make Japan's military more assertive despite popular opposition and constitutional restrictions, Parliament passed a law in July authorizing the sending of 1,000 troops to Iraq. The government postponed initial plans to dispatch the troops by the end of this year after the bombing of the United Nations' headquarters in Baghdad.
American officials have been pressing Japan to send the troops quickly and to commit money to Iraq's reconstruction. President Bush is expected to focus on these points during his scheduled visit here on Oct. 17.
"Bush wants Koizumi to send troops right now," said Aiji Tanaka, a professor of politics at Waseda University here. "But Koizumi knows that sending troops right now would hurt him in the general elections in November. So Koizumi will probably wait until the general elections are over, and using the popularity he enjoys, he will probably send troops to Iraq."
Although sending troops to Iraq, which might place Japanese soldiers in combat for the first time since World War II, is of limited military significance, it would carry great symbolic significance for both the Bush administration and Japan.
At home, today's strong backing from his own party could embolden Mr. Koizumi's efforts to push through painful economic measures by cutting public spending, reforming the bank industry, letting weak companies fail and privatizing the postal service and road maintenance companies. His own party members especially have resisted the privatization plans, which would bring an end to appointed government jobs that have traditionally been used to reward party faithful. 
To win today, Mr. Koizumi secured the backing of several conservative power brokers inside the party, most notably Mikio Aoki, the leader of the lower house of Japan's Parliament. Mr. Akio, who has been one of the most vocal critics of Mr. Koizumi's reforms, clearly needs the prime minister's support in upper house elections next July. 
A test of how forcefully Mr. Koizumi plans to push ahead with reforms, or whether he is beholden to conservatives like Mr. Aoki, might come on Monday, when the prime minister reshuffles his cabinet. What happens to reformers like Heizo Takenaka, the economics and financial services minister who has been the focal point of conservative anger, will send out strong signals. 
Since it was formed in 1955, the Liberal Democratic Party has been divided into factions headed by powerful figures. The factions have been the traditional conduit for patronage, power and corruption, but have been weakened in recent years because of political reforms and Mr. Koizumi's policies.
Perhaps signaling the end of the party's factional system, lawmakers who hope to ride Mr. Koizumi's coattails in the coming general election revolted against their faction leaders to support Mr. Koizumi in today's vote. While not as wildly popular as he was when he was first elected in 2001, Mr. Koizumi still has a 50 percent approval rating, according to recent polls.
In today's party election, 357 lawmakers cast one vote each, and 300 votes were compiled from the party's 1.4 million members nationwide. Mr. Koizumi won 399 out of 657 votes, or almost 61 percent. 
Yasunori Sone, a professor of politics at Keio University here, said that Mr. Koizumi's support was especially strong among the party members nationwide, suggesting broad acceptance of his policies, even though his spending cuts and other reforms during his first term had hurt them most.
Mr. Koizumi will have a strong mandate to push through reforms, especially after upper house elections next July, Mr. Sone said. "There won't be any elections for three years after that," he added, "so he'll be able to do anything he wants."
Shizuka Kamei, 66, a former party policy chief, came in second in today's poll with 139 votes; Masahiko Komura, 61, a former foreign minister, received 54 votes; Takao Fujii, 60, a former transportation minister who, as the candidate of the biggest Liberal Democratic faction, would have normally been the winner in the past, won 65 votes. All three had advocated more public spending to revive the economy.
The collapse of the factions coincides with new challenges the party is facing from the decision by the two opposition parties, the Democratic Party and the Liberal Party, to merge. The Democratic Party has had electoral successes in recent parliamentary by-elections, especially in urban areas and among young voters. The Liberal Democratic Party still draws strong support in rural areas and among older voters.
"Now, the next real choice: whether all the people and the voters really agree to maintain the Koizumi government or they want a change in power," Naoto Kan, the leader of the newly merged Democratic Party, said in a television interview after today's results.
Experts predict that Mr. Koizumi's party will hold on to power in the coming elections. But, in 2006, when term limits would force Mr. Koizumi to retire, it could lose its grip if no attractive successor emerges within the party, they say.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Bans Foreign Aid Workers From Embattled Province 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
The province of Aceh, where the United Nations estimates that 100,000 people have been displaced as a result of fighting there, is without any foreign aid workers because Indonesia has refused to give them permits, say officials with the United Nations and other organizations. 
 A World Health Organization worker, who left Aceh on Friday because his permit was about to expire, was the last international aid worker in the province, United Nations officials said. 
 The Indonesian government has justified the virtual ban by saying that foreigners are in danger of being kidnapped by the separatist rebels of the Free Aceh Movement. 
The government insists that it is capable of distributing food and health supplies to civilians who have fled their homes. Many are living in government camps.
The United States Agency for International Development, which ran a small program in Aceh, no longer has any American workers in the province, an American official said. 
The International Committee for the Red Cross has suspended its efforts to visit detainees held by both sides in the conflict after the government refused to issue permits to Red Cross workers that would allow them to travel in the province. 
The government's closed door is relatively unusual in a country that has received substantial development aid over many years from leading donors -- the United States, the European Union, Japan, the United Nations and the World Bank.
Soon after the government imposed martial law in Aceh in May, the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, issued a statement urging Indonesia to ensure the safety of aid workers and ensure their access to people in need. Martial law continues. 
But Indonesia has ignored Mr. Annan's warning, and the question of foreign aid workers has become so urgent that it is likely to be raised with the Indonesian president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, when she visits the United Nations next week, senior United Nations officials said. 
The decision to keep foreign aid workers out of the province is enforced by a Ministry of Justice decree issued after the start of the army offensive on May 16. It sets up a special visa system for Aceh. 
United Nations officials said they requested 13 special visas for foreign staff workers in Aceh. Two were granted, and those have now expired, they said.
A Human Rights Watch report issued on Friday said that because of scant information it was difficult to assess precisely how the population of 4.2 million, most of whom live outside the two main cities, was surviving. But it was known that more than 500 schools had been burned down. The International Organization for Migration, a United Nations body, said 100,000 people had been displaced by the fighting, although many had since managed to return to their homes. 
The Indonesian government reacted angrily to the Human Rights Watch report. "It's very arrogant for an agency like Human Rights Watch to think that because they can't get access to certain places like Aceh, because they don't have eyes and ears and mouths, therefore the situation there is closed and there must be rights abuses," said the spokesman for the Department of Foreign Affairs, Marty Natalegawa. 
Kontras, an Indonesian nongovernmental human rights group based in Jakarta, has been forced to work underground in Aceh, the group's director, Usman Hamid, said today.
