HEADLINE: Divorce in South Korea: Striking a New Attitude 

BYLINE:  By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
Only a decade ago, Sunoo, one of South Korea's largest matchmaking services, had no divorced clients. Few Koreans divorced anyway, and deep social prejudice forced those who did to resign themselves to a life of solitude.
 Today, with a surging divorce rate that now ranks among the world's highest, divorced clients account for 15 percent of Sunoo's membership. But as with other agencies that match people looking to marry, Sunoo keeps its divorced members in a largely separate category. 
 "South Korea is in a transition," said Lee Woong Jin, 38, the agency's chief executive. "It's a reality that divorce is rising and will probably continue to rise. At the same time, we are adhering to traditional values." 
Rapidly changing attitudes toward divorce -- as well as such other issues as marriage, childbearing and cohabitation -- show a South Korea in the throes of a social transformation. Still anchored in Confucian values of family and patriarchy, South Korea is fast becoming an open, Westernized society -- with the world's highest concentration of Internet broadband users, a pop culture that has recently been breaking taboos left and right, and living patterns increasingly focusing on individual satisfaction.
Social changes that took decades in the West or Japan, sociologists here like to point out, are occurring here in a matter of years. In the last decade, South Korea's divorce rate swelled 250 percent, in keeping with women's rising social status. But it shot up even more after the economic crisis of 1997, which caused widespread unemployment and shook men's basic standing in the society and family, said Hwang Hee Bong, a deputy director at the Korea National Statistical Office.
"I personally feel a big change compared with five years ago," said Lee Yoon Jung, 33, who initiated divorce proceedings in 1998 after concluding that she and her husband could not resolve their personality conflicts. "People would say, 'How could you divorce? You absolutely cannot divorce.' Now, people say, 'If you aren't a good match, you don't necessarily have to stay together.' "
"I have a job and money," added Ms. Lee, who works for a shipping company. "If there is a good person, I'd like to get remarried. But I don't want to get restricted in a bad situation."
The divorce rate last year was 3 cases for every 1,000 people, government statistics show, up from 2 in 1997. 
In 2001, the rate was 2.8, which was above the European Union's average of 1.8 and Japan's 2.3, though below the United States' rate of 4.
"I think this overall trend will keep on rising," Mr. Hwang said.
Also, the marriage rate -- lower than the United States' and higher than Europe's and Japan's -- has been declining. People are marrying later and having fewer children. Last year, the birth rate was 1.17 children per woman, even lower than Japan's 1.32.
In addition, more young couples are defying a longtime taboo against living together, though they largely keep the fact hidden from their parents and co-workers. Moving in together has become such a phenomenon that a recent television series, "A Cat in the Rooftop Room," became a hit by tackling the issue. 
South Korean popular culture, perhaps like America's in the 1970's, is overflowing with taboo-shattering shows. Another hit television show, "The Woman Next Door" -- which has been called the Korean "Sex and the City" -- focuses on the marriages and extramarital affairs of three women in their 30's. The show describes a radical departure, social critics have pointed out, from the days when men engaged in affairs and wives endured in silence.
The longest-running of these shows, "Love and War," was the first to deal with divorce when it appeared four years ago and has consistently ranked in the top 10. It recreates stories of troubled marriages based on real cases, after which viewers vote on whether the couple should divorce. (The vote is for divorce in 80 percent of the episodes.)
Jang Seong Hwan, 46, the show's executive producer, said he created it after the spike in divorce in the wake of the 1997 economic crisis. "We wanted to bring on television issues that were never discussed in public, in part to stop the divorce rate from rising," Mr. Jang said. But some viewers have accused the show of encouraging divorce by giving the issue such prominence, he added.
Still, the program also shows the boundaries of social change. While it calls itself a reality-based show, only actors appear. "It's impossible to ask real couples to come," Mr. Jang said. "They would not want to reveal their faces and names."
Divorce, once almost nonexistent, first appeared in significant numbers in the 1970's, as Koreans moved from rural areas into cities, said Kwak Bae Hee, an expert on divorce and the president of the Korea Legal Aid Center for Family Relations, a partly government-financed organization that counsels couples. Apartment-dwelling couples no longer living with their relatives felt less pressure to stay together.
Over the years, divorce laws that discriminated against women were also changed, Ms. Kwak said. But the surge in divorce in the 1990's, she said, came as women became better educated and more of them held jobs. Now women are more likely to feel that they are entitled to seek personal happiness, she said. The majority of divorces are initiated by women, and personality conflict is the reason cited most often.
"Men found the political and economic changes difficult to adapt to, but they thought that the family would at least stay the same," Ms. Kwak said. "But the fact is that of all the institutions in Korean society, the family may be the one that has undergone the biggest change."
Lee Ji Yong, 38, a civil engineer who earned his master's degree in the United States, married about a decade ago. His wife, a flight attendant with Northwest Airlines, chose to keep working after marrying. They have two daughters.
"There was a conflict from the start,"Mr. Lee said. "After work, I wanted her in the house, with her apron, preparing a hot meal for me. But she wanted her career."
His wife asked for a divorce, said Mr. Lee, and after consulting with his parents, he agreed. After their divorce last year, Mr. Lee joined Sunoo's remarriage section and became engaged to a divorced woman.
With a growing pool of divorced people, the chances of remarrying have increased, even though lingering prejudices confine the choices largely to other divorced people.
For the foreseeable future, matchmaking services, said Sunoo's Mr. Lee, will continue to introduce divorced people largely to one another. (Though in this youth-obsessed culture, women ages 32 and over are now confined to Sunoo's registry of the divorced.)
Yoo Hae Ok, 44, said she never expected to remarry after divorcing her husband 10 years ago, especially as a single mother of two boys. But with her children now in college, Ms. Yoo, who has been working as a remarriage adviser for a matchmaking service called Piery for the last five years, married a divorced man last year and is happy.
Yet she is aware that society still looks askance at divorced women, often labeling them promiscuous or heavy drinkers. 
"I'm very cautious about the way I behave at social gatherings," Ms. Yoo said. "If I make a mistake, people will say that's why I was divorced."
Talking openly about one's divorce is something Koreans still seldom do, and doing so brought tears to Ms. Yoo's eyes. "My husband was irresponsible toward the family," she said. "I was hoping that he would change -- he is my children's father, after all."
"Society has changed a lot," she added. "In the past, if men had affairs or neglected the family, our mothers and grandmothers would have tolerated that. Now women don't want to tolerate that kind of situation."

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM INDIANAPOLIS; 
With Respect, a State Pauses (Even Its Politicians)

BYLINE:  By Monica Davey

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS 

 BODY:
This is the time of year when the legislators have gone home and the Indiana Capitol stands mostly empty and silent.
 On Thursday, large crowds returned, passing through the oversize wood doors and down the long, creamy marble halls all day and late into the evening. But the normal hubbub of workaday government, all clicking heels and purposeful chatter, did not. 
 Instead, there was a hush. The people who filtered in beneath the line of ornate chandeliers took gentle steps, somberly processing past three wooden panels covered in photographs of Frank L. O'Bannon. 
Mr. O'Bannon, who died last weekend from a stroke, was governor -- and in many cases boss -- to the lawyers and bureaucrats, staffers and flacks, officials and regular people filing by. But in their whispers, they spoke of him more like a grandfather, someone who had never seemed quite scary enough to be chief executive.
Here was Mr. O'Bannon as a gangly high schooler, suited up for his basketball squad, the 1946 Corydon Panthers. There was Mr. O'Bannon dancing with his wife, Judy. Mr. O'Bannon fishing. Mr. O'Bannon surrounded by his family in their Christmas card. Mr. O'Bannon with his signature twinkling grin and reassuring thumbs up.
Farther down the hall, in the vast rotunda, Mr. O'Bannon's official portrait was flanked by two state police officers, who wore full dress uniforms and stood rigidly at attention. They made oddly formal companions to the friendly-looking fellow in the picture.
Tyree Coleman, a bailiff in the county court here, moved slowly and grim-faced through the images. He used to cut the governor's grass. "It's rare when you find a politician who isn't a politician," said Mr. Coleman, 23. "He was truly a down-home individual."
Perhaps not surprisingly, all politicking stopped in Indianapolis this week -- the result of good manners, of course, but also affection.
The sorrowful pause, in a state with a raging governor's race, has been almost as awkward for Mr. O'Bannon's friends as it has been for his enemies. As partisan competition went on hold, people mourned and tried to sort out what an appropriate memorial break might be in a case like this. As one politician here pointed out unhappily this week, there is no rule book on such things.
The battle for Mr. O'Bannon's job grew fierce long before Mr. O'Bannon's stroke -- and, in some cases, even before the 2000 presidential election votes were counted in Florida. Mr. O'Bannon, a Democrat and a powerful veteran of the state's party, could not have run again. State term limits would have required him to leave office in 16 months, at the end of his second four years. And the crowd of politicians who aspired to run for governor in 2004 knew that an open seat would be easier to win. 
By the time Mr. O'Bannon was hospitalized less than two weeks ago, the campaign had reached a rolling boil with the election still more than a year away. A few weeks before, the Democrats had held a straw poll for their candidates in French Lick. And earlier this month, President Bush appeared here with the most prominent Republican contender, the former White House budget director Mitchell E. Daniels Jr. He called him "my man Mitch."
Sometime soon -- probably next week -- the politicking will resume. Political operatives here have already begun privately trying to sort out what exactly Governor O'Bannon's death may mean for the race now.
It is never easy to run against the record of a likable person, as some O'Bannon opponents acknowledged they learned years ago. Crass as it may sound, it is only that much harder to run against the record of a likable person who has just died.
Still, Mr. O'Bannon's overall ratings had dipped significantly in the past few years, mostly because of the economic downturn that pounded Indiana even harder than other states. The state, which has a strong manufacturing base, lost thousands of jobs. Foreclosures and bankruptcies soared. State revenues sank. 
So the next governor's challenge had seemed obvious: find a way to turn things around by bringing in new jobs, retraining workers, growing state coffers or cutting costs. And Republicans saw their chance to retake the governor's job after 16 years, in a state that has not voted for a Democrat for president since 1964.
But now, running against the O'Bannon record suddenly looks far less palatable. 
"There may be less use of the word 'O'Bannon,' " Luke Messer, the executive director of the state's Republican Party, acknowledged the other day in an interview in the party's headquarters, a few blocks from the Capitol. "I think there will still be describing of the Democratic leadership, more generally, over the past 16 years." 
That could be a tricky line to walk. 
Mr. Daniels, one of four Republican candidates, said this week that he had always "admired and praised" the governor as a person, and would miss him a lot. "I never did and never would have anything critical to say about him," he said. "I am campaigning against the decline of our state."
Another question has emerged that will nag at all the candidates, Republican or Democrat. With Mr. O'Bannon's death, Lt. Gov. Joseph E. Kernan, his longtime Democratic running mate and his close friend, was sworn in as governor.
Mr. Kernan, a former South Bend mayor and a P.O.W. in Vietnam, had once been seen as the likeliest Democrat to replace Mr. O'Bannon, but he announced last year that he would not run. He said he was thinking about going home to South Bend, and maybe helping to buy the minor league baseball team there.
Democrats -- who had seen Mr. Kernan as their strongest candidate -- are now likely to urge him to reconsider, particularly since he would have the potent advantage of incumbency.
Mr. Kernan has been asked about it a lot the past few weeks. On a recent afternoon, he seemed weary of the question. "As I have said, nothing that's happened in the last 10 days has caused me to change my mind," he said. 
Some here -- particularly some among the current candidates, who would be most affected by the threat of Mr. Kernan -- say they feel certain he will not run. One candidate, Joe Andrew, the former national Democratic chairman, said he was "completely convinced" of that. 
But others wonder, perhaps hopefully, if Mr. Kernan might step in one of these days and make a fiery race even more of a fight.
On Friday afternoon, thousands poured onto the mall outside the Capitol, where Mr. O'Bannon had held his first inaugural, to which he had invited all of the state's fourth graders.
Indiana people, the new governor told those at the memorial, have been arguing for years about the word "Hoosier," the nickname for state residents. "I think we know what the definition is," Mr. Kernan said. "It's Frank O'Bannon."
A group of children played "Back Home Again in Indiana" as Mrs. O'Bannon sang along. A pack of doves was released. An honor guard set off a 19-round artillery salute, breaking the quiet and sending a puff of white smoke into the sky over the Capitol.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A memorial service for Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon was held Friday on the mall outside the Capitol in Indianapolis. The candidates in a contentious race to succeed him took a break from politicking after his death last weekend. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: State Gives Museum $5 Million 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
ARENOVATION and expansion plan that would more than double the size of the New Britain Museum of American Art took a giant step toward reality last week when Connecticut donated $5 million for the project.
 The announcement of the financing was made last Wednesday by Gov. John G. Rowland, who appeared at the museum at a ceremony attended by trustees, donors and volunteers. 
 "As the Governor said, this really turbocharges our campaign," said Douglas Hyland, director of the museum. "Everyone is just enthused and revitalized by this news."
Individual and corporate donors have already raised $11 million for the project, which is expected to cost $25 million. This is the first capital campaign for the institution, which has an extensive collection of American art, including canvases by painters of the Hudson River School, and murals by Thomas Hart Benton. The museum is celebrating its centennial this year.
The project is a bold move in a fragile economy when other cultural institutions in the area are reconsidering construction plans.
The larger and better-known Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, for instance, has decided to forego its planned $80 million expansion and renovation plan and may pursue a more modest goal. But Mr. Hyland said the time was right for New Britain.
"The impetus is the ever-growing influence of the museum in this region," said Mr. Hyland, who left the San Antonio Museum of Art to become director here four years ago.
Mr. Hyland said museum visitors reflected the city's diversity. "We've become a hub for a variety of different community groups," he said.
The museum certainly needs more space. It is housed in a circa 1903 house, with room for just 4 percent of the 5,000 works in the collection to be on view. The current museum is 25,000 square feet. The renovated building, with the additions, would be 53,000 square feet.
The main house of the existing museum, which has a 15-year-old addition, includes galleries with fireplaces, wood floors that creak underfoot and library tables topped with art books and fresh flowers. A visitor wandering through the rooms feels a bit like a very lucky guest at a party in a grand house whose owners have exquisite taste. Mr. Hyland said he wanted the new museum to retain elements of that charm.
The plan was designed by Ann Beha, a Boston architect. In addition to new galleries, it calls for a new lobby, program space, auditorium, studios and gift shop.
To rise to the expectations of today's museumgoers, the project will also include an amenity the museum does not have -- a cafe. It will overlook Walnut Hill Park, a Frederick Law Olmsted design whose tree-dotted hills cause viewers to double-take from canvas to window in the gallery of American Impressionists.
The renovation will also address some mundane but essential needs. A recently purchased adjacent half-acre of land will become a parking lot; on-street parking is the only current choice.
Construction is expected to begin next summer and to take two years. The museum will not close during construction, but its hours may be abbreviated.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Loving the Landscape That We Call Home

BYLINE:  By HELEN A. HARRISON

 BODY:
LONG Island landscape painting celebrates its bicentenary this year, and exhibitions in Setauket and East Hampton prove that the local landscape continues to inspire contemporary artists. 
 The earliest known example of landscape painting here is an 1803 watercolor by Elizabeth Sleight of Sag Harbor. As the United States's first port of entry, Sag Harbor was a center of maritime commerce, especially in the early 19th century. Ms. Sleight's charming view of the village's harbor, a copy of which is in Sag Harbor's John Jermain Library, shows the port at the dawn of its heyday, with the wharves, warehouses and other amenities for the cargo ships and whaling vessels that linked the East End to New England and the wider world. 
 But the landscape tradition did not really take root here until the mid 19th century, after the Hudson River School painters had established a taste for scenic vistas. William Sidney Mount, a Setauket native, was among the first to exploit this new enthusiasm, painting studies of the Island's rural life that combined human interest with lovingly rendered views of the environment.
After 1845, as the expanding railroad simplified travel to and from New York City, more people were drawn to the East End's rustic villages and unspoiled maritime scenery. Paintings of shingled cottages, jaunty sailboats, ocean bathers and lighthouses began to appear in the city's galleries.
 Even then, there was nostalgia for the simple pleasures of country living, which lured artists and tourists alike. In 1852, the East Hampton novelist Cornelia Huntington wrote that the area's reputation had already encouraged "troops of seekers after change to explore all the sweet secluded nooks and shady retreats" and "take possession by right of discovery."
 The work of contemporary landscape artists shares Mount's reverence for the vistas of rural Long Island, but is also occasionally tinged with the ambivalence expressed in Ms. Huntington's observation. 
 At Lizan-Tops Gallery in East Hampton, the 10th annual Long Island landscape exhibition focuses on "Preserving the Landscape." The theme highlights issues raised by the town's proposal for a plan on growth. Whether implicitly or directly, much of the art depicts an environment threatened by development and the loss of agricultural and maritime enterprises. 
 Among the most poignant images are Joan Baren's drawings of old East End farmhouses and outbuildings, shown falling into disrepair and surrounded by neglected gardens and fallow fields. Her delicate, feathery line technique weaves together natural and man-made forms, stressing the harmony of the structures and their surroundings, but also their fragility.
 The farms in Ralph Carpentier's paintings look more substantial, with occasional humans and animals to indicate active use. Countering the area's reputation as a summer resort, he includes a couple of snow scenes that emphasize the low density of agricultural settlement, with a few clustered buildings surrounded by open fields.
 In "Harvest," a 1983 canvas, Robert Dash focuses on the land's richness. In the image, lush foliage creates patterns of dappled sunlight on the freshly turned earth.
 The shoreline is another favorite subject for local landscapists, among them Mr. Carpentier, Jane Freilicher, Mike Solomon, Cynthia Knott and Christian Brechneff.
 Mr. Solomon's watercolor sketches of deserted ocean beaches -- diaristic observations by an avid surfer -- sensitively record specific times and weather conditions, while Ms. Freilicher's oil, "The Beginning of Summer," documents the view from the artist's Water Mill studio. Her earliest paintings of this subject showed an uninterrupted vista to the pond and dunes beyond, but now the land is punctuated by beach houses, the area's primary cash crop.
 Janet Jennings's studies of tidal inlets highlight the interaction of land and water. In her "Pond of Pines" paintings, glowing reflections contrast with the earthy tones of marsh grass and surrounding woods.
 In Setauket, Gallery North's annual "Local Color" exhibition is similar in content, although less pointed in its references to change and potential loss.
Doug Reina's bright, sunny beach scenes, with old-fashioned summer cottages up on stilts at the water's edge, celebrate the unpretentious type of waterfront development that has been supplanted by McMansions on the dunes. The warm glow of afternoon creates a cozy feeling in Marion McManus' "Salt Air," with its distant view of shoreline cottages seen across a grassy field. Both artists suggest that smaller is better, more in tune with the natural environment.
 Wooden boats staked to the shore in Dominick DiLorenzo's "Mooring on Hallock's Bay" affirm the joys of rowing and sailing -- no noisy, oily outboard motors for the purists who own these pleasure craft. The tranquil scene, with water gently lapping against an unpaved launching ramp, is an homage to the "sweet secluded nooks" that are so abundant on the coast. Carlina Valenti's lovingly rendered still lifes of farm stand produce are reminders that agriculture continues to be a mainstay of the local economy, even if the market is increasingly tied to tourism. But that trend has a long history. Looking back over the Island's landscape painting tradition, one can see the evidence that people have come here "to rusticate and rest," as Huntington put it, for the better part of two centuries.
 "Preserving the Landscape" is at Lizan-Tops Gallery, 66 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, (631)324-3424, through Sept. 28. "Local Color" is at Gallery North, 90 North Country Road, Setauket, (631)751-2676, through Sept. 24.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Local landscapes are the subject of two shows. Doug Reina's "Brown Cottage," left, and Dominick DiLorenzo's "Morning on Hallock's Bay," below, left, are on view at Gallery North in Setauket. Janet Jennings's "Pond of Pines II," far left, and Robert Dash's "Harvest" are on display at Lizan-Tops Gallery in East Hampton.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
A Corner Transformed, and Jobs Created

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
ON a busy day this summer, it was standing room only in Fortunoff's cramped human resources office on East Post Road. 
 The reason for the anxious hordes was simple: The company received 9,000 resumes of applicants for the 700 new jobs at its new store here. If you're a company hiring 700 new employees in a little more than four months, you have got to interview at least eight people for each one you hire, according to Norman Goldberg, a former chief executive officer who was invited back by the Fortunoff family to supervise marketing and advertising for the new store. 
 Fortunoff, the family-owned jewelry and home furnishings store, opened a new 185,000-square-foot store in White Plains this week, and began hiring employees on May 17. Since then, Mr. Goldberg and his staff have interviewed 4,800 people. During July, the peak hiring season, Fortunoff was interviewing between 140 and 160 people a day, Mr. Goldberg said. 
"There are people out there who need work, and we have work," he said. Mr. Goldberg, who always comes to work dressed in a suit and tie, said that he conducted at least two interviews a day himself, "because I don't want to walk into the store and say, 'Did I hire these people?"'
Since early summer, Fortunoff has hired about 650 employees between the ages of 18 and 72. Half live in Westchester County, and half are full-time workers, Mr. Goldberg said. The company is still hiring, with a special effort to recruit on nearby college campuses, with a goal of 750 employees by the end of this month, which will make Fortunoff among the top 25 largest private sector employers in Westchester.
After spending 20 years trying to find a suitable location in Westchester, Louis Fortunoff, executive vice president, said he is ecstatic that the store is built and open for customers, and "we're ready to show Westchester what we're all about."
Eighty years ago, Mr. Fortunoff's grandparents opened a store on Livonia Avenue in Brooklyn that sold just pots and pans. In time, the early Fortunoff included seven shops in New York City, with the first suburban store opening in Westbury on Long Island in 1964. Today, still a privately held family business, it is run by nine family members, all executive vice presidents, including Mr. Fortunoff's mother, Helene, who started Fortunoff's jewelry department in 1957.
The White Plains store is the sixth in the chain, which is based in Uniondale on Long Island. (Other locations are on Long Island, in New Jersey and Manhattan.) The new store is in a newly built four-story building on a somewhat neglected corner of White Plains, just opposite The Westchester mall and down the road from the Westchester Pavilion. The top three floors will house Fortunoff. There, customers will have a choice of 5,000 watches, 10,000 pairs of earrings, 15,000 Christmas ornaments and decorations, 1,500 clocks, 70 decorated beds and even 15 imported bathroom sinks.
The street-level floor will include two restaurants, the Cheesecake Factory, a national chain based in Calabasas Hills, Calif., which is now open, and Morton's, the Steakhouse. The steakhouse and Whole Foods Market, an outpost of a grocery store chain from Austin, Tex., are both set to open in spring of 2004.
This combination, of Fortunoff merchandise along with two successful restaurant chains and an organic food market, is a smart marketing move, said Howard Davidowitz, owner of Davidowitz & Associates Inc., a national retail consulting firm in New York City
"First, Fortunoff married jewelry and home furnishing, and now they've added food to generate footsteps," he said, adding that "the place will be an extravaganza."
Despite the struggling national economy, Mr. Fortunoff said he expects the store to do at least $86 million in sales during the first year. "Westchester is the most resilient of all the regions in the metropolitan New York area, and has the lowest unemployment," he said. 
The six-acre site, at the corner of Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road, had been occupied by Saks Fifth Avenue for 50 years, and was sold to Fortunoff in 2001 for $14 million. Mr. Fortunoff said the company spent $66 million on construction, $12 million on legal and other fees and $12 million on interior design and fixtures. 
The 265,000-square-foot development was financed by a $72 million taxable bond issued by the Westchester County Industrial Development Agency and backed by a letter of credit from a five-member bank group, led by Buffalo-based M & T Bank, Mr. Fortunoff said. 
Issuing a taxable bond for a retail business was highly unusual for Westchester's Industrial Development Agency, said Theresa G. Waivada, the agency's executive director. But the Fortunoff project was eligible because it was adjacent to a census tract with a high poverty and unemployment rate, and because it was part of a White Plains downtown revitalization, she explained.
The project was important for the city and the county, she said, "so that this prime piece of property would not remain vacant, and because it will generate a great deal of sales tax." 
Ms. Waivada's agency also gave Fortunoff a sales tax exemption on construction costs worth $1 million. 
The county's foregone tax revenue and other aid to the project will bring substantial returns, Ms. Waivada said. The development "will generate multiple visits, and people who work there will shop in downtown White Plains," she said, adding that "everything sold in that complex is subject to sales tax."
Mr. Fortunoff estimated that the complex should bring in about $9.9 million in city, county and state tax revenues the first year, about $6.7 million of that from Fortunoff alone. 
The birth of the new Fortunoff store has many county officials as proud as new parents of quadruplets. "It provides a central marketplace for Westchester and the surrounding area," said the County Executive Andrew J. Spano. "There's a certain panache about Fortunoff." 
Because Fortunoff is privately owned and does not disclose financial statements, the company's profits and operating costs are not made available to stock analysts. "There are very few private companies in America of Fortunoff's size where the family is still running it," Mr. Davidowitz said. But with a financial investment as large as the one in the new White Plains store, he said, "the family is playing 'You Bet Your Life,' and their lives are on the line."
One of the lucky new employees is Bernard Danuff of Syosset on Long Island, who at 72 has been in the jewelry business for 50 years, and has also been a Fortunoff customer. After he was hired, he took about 200 hours of training before he began to sell fine watches in White Plains this week.
Not so lucky was Russell Brod, 60, of White Plains, who was interviewed twice for a job in store design and display, and spent four days working at several Fortunoff stores rearranging rooms of furniture. "I was a little disappointed, but I can't be angry with someone who doesn't hire me," he said. Though he didn't get the job, he still got four days of pay.

The outside of the store, which sits at the corner of Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hospital Cuts Ties to St. Agnes 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

 BODY:
WHEN Westchester Medical Center decided to abandon the former St. Agnes Hospital not long ago, only five months after a rather hasty but much-praised marriage, questions were raised immediately about what had caused the sudden split.
 Depending on who is answering, several reasons for the split may be given, and all of them seem to relate to money. The medical center in Valhalla took over St. Agnes after it gave up its medical license in April under crushing debt. Just two months ago, everybody from the chief executive of the medical center to the creditors of St. Agnes, a small Catholic hospital in White Plains, seemed optimistic about the union. Then, suddenly, a little more than a week ago, Westchester Medical said it would end the partnership in early October at the close of a six-month trial period. 
 Mary de Barros, a spokeswoman for the former St. Agnes, said the cause was $36 million in debt that St. Agnes had accrued in a loan from the New York State Dormitory Authority in 2001. 
Whoever runs St. Agnes will need to pay close to $3 million annually on the debt to the Dormitory Authority, said the authority's spokeswoman, Claudia Hutton. The medical center didn't make debt payments in the six-month trial period, by agreement with the dormitory authority, and it didn't settle on a permanent repayment plan before it took over St. Agnes.
Gene Capello, the chairman of the medical center's board, said the split was the result of conclusions drawn in a recent consultant report commissioned by the medical center. 
"The report says that we will lose $7 million a year by operating the St. Agnes campus," said Mr. Capello, who received the report earlier this month. "We haven't even considered the Dormitory Authority debt."
The consultant's report said the medical center as a whole lost $58 million on $500 million of revenue in 2002, before St. Agnes was even in the picture, Mr. Capello said. In July, Edward Stolzenberg, the medical center's chief executive, told reporters that the medical center's loss for 2002 was more than $10 million and less than $15 million. 
Craig Kornett, an analyst at Fitch Ratings who specializes in the health care industry, said that the large loss incurred last year at the medical center is unusual even among cash-strapped hospitals, but that the hospital is not yet in any danger of closing.
Both Mr. Capello and Carin Grossman, a hospital spokeswoman, said this week that Mr. Stolzenberg, 57, is going to retire at the end of this year because of heart problems. Ms. Grossman said that decision and the financial troubles of the medical center are not related. Through Ms. Grossman, Mr. Stolzenberg declined to comment for this article.
Richard L. Brodsky, the state assemblyman from Greenburgh who leads an Assembly committee overseeing the Dormitory Authority, blames the state agency.
"We had asked the Dormitory Authority to work out a financial plan with St. Agnes and Westchester Medical Center so they aren't losing so much money," Mr. Brodsky said, "but the agency refused to do it."
Ms. Hutton said the Dormitory Authority, which issues bonds on Wall Street, cannot restructure debt payments since money is paid to bondholders periodically.

HEADLINE: Group of 7's Economic Officials Urge Reopening of Trade Talks 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

DATELINE: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
On a day that included discussions ranging from terrorist financing to disclosures of questionable uses of public funds by the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, representatives of the Group of Seven richest nations called for the resumption of world trade talks and a global commitment to market-based exchange rates for currencies.
 In a communique released this evening, the Group of 7 said it "reaffirms that exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals," a statement that was a barely disguised criticism of the currency policies of China and Japan. Central bankers around the globe have routinely criticized both countries for intervening in currency markets to keep their currencies artificially low, policies that also lower their export prices and thus boost their share of international trade. 
 China, which has long protected its currency to guard against the vicissitudes of global economic swings, successfully weathered the currency panics that beset many of its Asian neighbors during the late 1990's and is unlikely to change its policy to appease the Group of 7. Japan, on the other hand, is something of a wild card. Although the yen rose to a two-and-a-half year high against the dollar on Friday in anticipation that the Bank of Japan would start buying yen to comply with the organization's wishes, currency traders may be overestimating how collegial Japan truly is. In the past, Japan has voiced its commitment to Group of 7 directives, only to then turn around and do the exact opposite.
The Group of 7 -- which includes Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, and the United States -- gathered during the annual World Bank and International Monetary Fund meeting here.
At a news conference during today's meeting, Karim Nashashibi, the I.M.F.'s representative in the West Bank and Gaza, disclosed an audit of the Palestinian Authority's finances that indicated that, since 1999, Mr. Arafat has channeled about $900 million in public funds into a bank account he controls. The funds were invested in nearly six dozen enterprises in the Palestinian territories and overseas. Mr. Nashashibi said he received the information about Mr. Arafat's accounts from the Palestinian Authority. The authority's finance minister, Salam Fayad, who has called for greater openness in his organization's accounting, attended today's meeting here and won commitments of more than $1 billion in financial aid for the Palestinians from industrialized countries.
It is unclear if any of the funds diverted by Mr. Arafat were misused. Mr. Nashashibi said that a final determination on that point awaits the completion of the audits.
Hanan Ashwari, a Palestinian legislator and onetime Arafat spokeswoman, acknowledged there had been incidents of misuse of funds in the past but that the release of the information was an attempt to discredit the Palestinian leader.
"There is nothing innocent about the timing," she said. "This is a campaign against the president and the authority."
Mr. Snow convened a meeting tonight with finance ministers from most of the major Persian Gulf states -- including Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the U.A.E. -- as well as Russia, Indonesia, Pakistan, India and the Philippines, in order to discuss greater global cooperation to counter terrorism and terrorist financing. Financial ministers said that countries are beginning to show a greater willingness to join hands in the effort, but that significant cultural and jurisdictional hurdles remain.

HEADLINE: Hunting for a Sitcom Hit Among the Misses 

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
This is what the television comedy desert looks like: a stark, white, fluorescent-lighted writing room in the Billy Wilder building on the Paramount Studios lot. The room, the working quarters for the writers on a new ABC sitcom "It's All Relative," is furnished with nothing more than a long, wooden table, a couple of blackboards and a high stack of blank yellow legal pads, awaiting ideas. Nourishment lies solely with a pile of Polly-O string cheese and bottled water.
 Hollywood manufactures television comedy in drab, institutional rooms like this one every year. But the rooms have not produced a wildly popular sitcom in more than five years, since the debut of "Will & Grace" in 1998. It is one of only three such droughts in television history, a dry spell that has cost the television industry millions upon millions in unrealized profits while prompting dire pronouncements that the network sitcom -- a staple since "I Love Lucy" more than 50 years ago -- is dying. 
 But as the broadcast networks have done every fall for the past half century, they are betting a midsized nation's gross domestic product that they have sitcom hits in their new schedules. The new season officially starts Monday, and the six main broadcast networks are offering a total of 19 new sitcoms. So confident is ABC about "It's All Relative," the network is giving it the coveted time slot before its hit reality show, "The Bachelor," on Wednesday nights, beginning Oct. 1.
With the death of the actor John Ritter raising questions about whether one of ABC's most-watched comedies, "8 Simple Rules for Dating My Teenage Daughter," can thrive without him, the network needs "It's All Relative" to succeed more than ever. Sunday's Emmy Awards ceremony only underscores the network's need for popular shows: ABC had the fewest nominations of all of the major broadcast networks this year, and less than a third of HBO's total. 
"It's All Relative" has all the trappings of the traditional sitcom: It is about a soon-to-be-married couple from very different worlds. The producers, however, have come up with a twist -- the woman was raised by highly educated, wealthy gay men, while her fiance is the son of two bigoted Irish Catholic barkeepers.
Other than that contemporary plot complication, they are sticking to all the elements of the shop-worn sitcom -- the laugh track, the stilted, four-camera filming style, standard-issue sets. Success, they say, will not come from blowing up the sitcom form. Instead, smarter execution of the broad-based family-style comedy, from casting to writing, will lead to ratings nirvana.
Yet whatever hopes the ABC executives and the producers might have for the show, the chances of success are as unlikely as the prospective in-laws becoming best friends. It is a mathematical certainty that most new sitcoms fail each fall, even in good times. And as the show's producers grapple with both the supposed staleness of the sitcom and the nation's changing but still unsettled views on gay issues, they still must confront the usual (and often treacherous) creative tensions with network bosses.
That tension was evident on one of the staff's very first days in their new writing room in early July. The first matter on the agenda was a seemingly simple one: the name of the show. But network television is made by committee, and simplicity is often elusive.
The first episode carried the "It's All Relative" title, which the main writer-producer team of Chuck Ranberg and Anne Flett-Giordano believed to be too generic. The writers were lobbying for "Family Outing." ABC, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, though, had settled on "The Out-Laws," Mr. Ranberg told his team, another play on "out of the closet." The news was not taken well.
The writers, venting their frustration with the network, dashed off a list with dozens of other tongue-in-cheek title possibilities, including "Home O' Sexuals" and others that would not be suitable for print.
But Mr. Ranberg and Ms. Flett-Giordano have been through bigger challenges in their careers. Veterans of the sitcom wars, they lived through the travails of their last prime-time effort, "Encore! Encore!" in 1998 -- a significant comedown from their previous jobs on "Frasier" and "Kate and Allie."
With the actor Nathan Lane playing a Lothario opera singer-turned-vineyard owner, "Encore! Encore!" became a punch line for jokes about outlandishly bad television. Upon its debut The New York Observer wrote, "It's the 'Moose Murders' of sitcoms -- it won't be here past Halloween, but the recollection of its awfulness will give you untold delight for years to come."
"I spent three months in bed," Ms. Flett-Giordano said, recalling the experience.
Ultimately that show, Ms. Flett-Giordano said, was thevictim of television bureaucracy. She and Mr. Ranberg wanted the show to have a Broadway theme, while Mr. Lane wanted his character to be a chef. When they decided their differences were irreconcilable it was too late; the studio and the network had expended too much time and energy to landing a big star like Mr. Lane to turn back. The writers and Mr. Lane had to come up with something, quickly, she said, and the womanizing opera singer was born. NBC, which is owned by the General Electric Company, canceled the show by the winter.
"It's All Relative," in contrast, originated with Lloyd Braun, the chairman of ABC Entertainment. Given that corporate imprimatur and direction, everyone involved with the show knew essentially what it was from the start.
To produce the show, Susan Lyne, the president of ABC Entertainment, turned to producers Neil Meron and Craig Zadan, who had helped make her executive career when she was head of ABC's television movie unit by delivering productions including "Annie" and "Life With Judy Garland." Their idea for the program, she said, had what the others were lacking: a Romeo & Juliet central theme.
Mr. Meron and Mr. Zadan teamed up with Ms. Flett-Giordano and Mr. Ranberg, and the four agreed with ABC executives they would stick with the typical sitcom form, despite its bad name these days.
There are numerous theories about what is behind the drought in new comedies. A war-weary nation is not in the mood to laugh, some say. Others point to ever-larger corporate overlords who are draining the creativity out of television. But the leading theory holds that audiences have become bored with a seemingly tired form, where jokes could be spotted two commercial breaks away and laugh tracks erupt for comic bits that would have turned a packed comedy club silent.
Yet attempts to change the format have largely failed on network television. "The Job," which ABC placed on its schedule in 2001 and 2002, had no laugh track, used one camera instead of the usual four, and had a rogue cop as its central character. Critics loved it; audiences did not. Numerous shows on Fox that tried to revitalize the half-hour comedy, like "Greg the Bunny" (about foul-mouthed puppets) and "The Tick" (about underperforming superheroes), also flamed out in the ratings.
While Fox, which is owned by the News Corporation, is not shunning unconventional sitcoms this television season -- one new show, "Arrested Development," has no laugh track and a wacky central premise revolving around a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation -- ABC has decided to embrace the old style to achieve a ratings renaissance.
"The form has a bad name because a lot of the product has not been good," Mr. Meron said in an interview. "But it's worked from 'I Love Lucy' through 'Mary Tyler Moore' through 'Frasier.' "
"It's all about writing compelling characters that people want to spend time with every week," Ms. Flett-Giordano said. "The magic of 'Cheers' was you wanted to spend time in that bar because you liked those people."
That can mean taking jokes out, she said, even though the current vogue calls for packing as many jokes into a minute as it can hold.
"You can't sacrifice your characters for a good joke," Ms. Flett-Giordano said. "If it hurts your character's character, then you're doing more hurt than good for the laugh of the moment." For example, in one scene of an early episode of "It's All Relative," the groom-to-be complains to his fiancee about her "gay Gestapo" parents. Although the line was a favorite of the writers, the producers and network executives felt the line was too harsh for a likeable character. 
Mr. Meron and Mr. Zadan both said they believe another way to revitalize the sitcom form is by looking for actors from a different milieu, namely the theater. "With a lot of actors the problem is you might find they're funny in a room, but you put them in front of a live audience, they fall flat," Mr. Zadan said. "They don't have the comic timing that comes from acting in a theater."
Although three of the four parents are played by actors with considerable experience on Broadway, the cast member considered crucial to the show's success is Lenny Clarke. Mr. Clarke, a longtime stand-up comedian and player on sitcoms including "Lenny" and "The John Larroquette Show," plays the Irish Catholic father, Mason "Mace" O'Neill.
Mr. Clarke's character, executives said, represents another essential tactic in their attempt to recapture the same sitcom magic Norman Lear had with shows like "All in the Family" and "Maude." Test audiences, executives said, seem to accept insulting and off-color lines from Mr. Clarke that they might not accept from other actors.
So far, the producers and writers said, ABC has granted them leeway in feeding Mr. Clarke's character the controversial lines that will give the show its real seasoning.
But when it comes to content, some realities of big business are insurmountable. During a writing room discussion of a scene to take place at a movie theater Ms. Flett-Giordano noted that the movie the characters are watching cannot be "something in conflict" with Walt Disney, ABC's parent. (The writers have also had to refrain from mentioning brand names on the program so as not to possibly promote the products of competitors to ABC advertisers.)
The network executives do not limit their suggestions -- and to some of the writers, their meddling -- to concerns about corporate positioning. When the group submitted its first script the network deemed it somewhat lacking in character development and in what executives call "emotional threads." In the episode's main plotline, the blue-collar groom-to-be, Bobby, fumbles with the cappuccino machine in the pristine home of his in-laws-to-be and causes an attached pipe to break in the adjoining wall. He has to call his parents to come and help him fix it before his fiancee and her parents come home.
Stephanie Leifer, the ABC executive in charge of comedy development, said she asked the writers to "get beyond the funny of escalating mishaps" in the house.
"I was just making sure that as they're breaking this, it's not just about a pipe breaking," she added. "What is the underlying thing? What is this saying in the end about him? Is this ultimately something between him and Liz?"
She and Ms. Lyne said that if those questions are not addressed, audiences will tune out.
But for all the thought that had gone into accounting for audience reactions, executives had not prepared for any significant backlash over the show's gay theme. And the taping of the second episode in August brought with it an unwelcome surprise.
In one early scene, when the gay fathers kissed goodbye, on the lips, some in the audience groaned loudly.
Still, at the end of the taping the writers were feeling confident about the show's prospects. The taping was over by 11 p.m. Often a badly run show can go into the wee hours of the morning, as the writers traipse back and forth between the writers' room and the studio reworking scenes. And most of the audience stuck around to the end.
Before the audience was sent home, the stagehands brought out a cake with a few birthday candles. It was the birthday of Maggie Lawson, the actress who plays the fiancee, Liz. The audience sang "Happy Birthday" to her, and before she blew out the candles, someone yelled, "Make a wish!" Ms. Flett-Giordano shouted out her own: "Syndication!"

HEADLINE: A Dollar Squeeze in the Academy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Stanley Fish ("Colleges Caught in a Vise," Op-Ed, Sept. 18) is right to point out the difficulties faced by colleges and universities,whose costs are rising faster than their ability to collect tuition from parents or subsidies from government. 
 The fact that we have members of Congress so unfamiliar with basic economics that they think they can legislate lower tuition is simply one more illustration of basic and pervasive political failure in Washington.
As our economy becomes more and more dependent upon cheap foreign labor, anything produced wholly within our home economy -- including our system of higher education along with other routine economic functions like infrastructure, building construction and medical care -- will become increasingly unaffordable.
Unless we want to send our kids to college in Brazil or China, we're going to have to quit looking for people to blame and face up to the costs involved.

ROBERT DEAN
Redding, Conn., Sept. 18, 2003

HEADLINE: A Dollar Squeeze in the Academy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Doubtless Stanley Fish (Op-Ed, Sept. 18) is correct in his analysis of the economic squeeze facing most major public universities. 
Yet he does not address a major factor that is contributing to the problem. 
 As Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, has emphasized, our colleges are out of touch with the mainstream of American society. Many observers view the faculty as a group of left-leaning obscurantists more concerned with the subtleties of poststructuralism than with providing basic instruction. 
 As with all stereotypes, this perception is at best a partial truth. Yet our universities need to address the issue and, if necessary, make corrections. 
Until this is done, they are likely to find that legislators will continue to be skeptical about the need for more funds. In this they are reflecting the doubts of the public at large.

WAYNE R. DYNES
New York, Sept. 18, 2003

The writer is a professor of art history at Hunter College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
In the Market for a New Job? Start Packing

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton; This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
In theory, at least, you might want to move to Atlanta to find a new job. After all, that city and its suburbs have gained more than 47,000 jobs in the last year, while the New York metropolitan area has lost more than 50,000 jobs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 Looking for someplace more exotic? The area around McAllen, Tex., has the fastest-growing job market in the nation, according to the bureau -- though the 6,000 or so jobs it has gained in the last 12 months would barely make a dent in New York's unemployment problem. On the other hand, you can walk to Mexico from McAllen -- and it claims to be one of the cheapest places to live in the entire country. 
 New York State chauvinists might want to consider the Albany area, where, the State Department of Labor reported last week, the private-sector employment base has grown by 2,400 jobs in the 12 months ended August. Government jobs, on the other hand, have been disappearing, leaving the total job count down by 400.
The reverse situation prevails on Long Island, where the total number of jobs has jumped by 3,000, but the number of jobs in the private sector actually declined by 100.
Still, the suburbs -- especially the northern suburbs -- have been chugging along awfully well, economically speaking, even as the city has been sinking. Westchester, for example, added 2,100 jobs in the 12 months ended August, a gain of 0.5 percent; Rockland County added 1,700 jobs, or 1.5 percent.
That may not sound like much, but it is better than the national average -- and a lot better than the situation in the five boroughs. Almost 63,000 jobs have vaporized in the city in the last year, for a decline of 1.4 percent.
And the most recent economic news in New York City is decidedly mixed. The unemployment rate remained at 8.1 percent in August, for the third straight month, down slightly from the high of 8.8 percent of last February, but significantly higher than it has been in years.
In Westchester, by contrast, the jobless rate is only 4 percent, and in Putnam County, it is a measly 3.4 percent.
The number of jobs in the city, which some economists had hoped would stabilize or even rise last month, dropped by more than 12,000, according to Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist for the real estate company Jones Lang LaSalle. Ms. Denham takes government jobs data and adjusts it for seasonal factors.
Why has the city been suffering, economically, so much more than the suburbs? Well, the effects of 9/11 have to be a factor. But there are others.
One is simply the mix of businesses. Investment firms were among the hardest hit businesses in recent years, along with technology companies; both were disproportionately situated in the city and not on Long Island or in the northern suburbs, noted James P. Brown, an analyst with the New York State Department of Labor. "It was called Silicon Alley, not Silicon Beach," he said.
Even the same industry might perform very differently in the city than in the suburbs, he said, pointing to legal services as an example. While in many places the legal business is fueled by real estate work (and the housing market has continued to boom outside the city), legal services in Manhattan are often connected to Wall Street and serve corporations that have been cutting back.
Furthermore, people continue to push out into areas of the suburbs that were farmland not too long ago. And with them come new homes -- and construction jobs. And new stores -- and retailing jobs. And schoolteachers, doctors, nurses, lawyers, dry cleaners, and just about every other kind of service worker that there is.
Growth has been strong all along the Hudson Valley, said Sean P. MacDonald, an associate economist for the Labor Department, but particularly in Orange and Dutchess Counties, she said, "which used to be really rural."
So even a die-hard New York City dweller might want to consider looking outside the boroughs for employment. "Someone from the Bronx might not want to commute to Westchester or New Jersey, but there are jobs there," said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
On the other hand, Mr. Bram said, the most important thing may not be where you live or work, but what you want to do.
Factory work continues to disappear all over the United States, but it has been almost absent from New York City for decades. Jobs in health care, on the other hand, continue to boom, and construction and retailing are showing strength. 
"The best advice," Mr. Bram said, "is to be in an industry that's doing well."

HEADLINE: Clark's Military Record Offers Campaign Clues 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
This was Wesley K. Clark at his best.
 As the senior military negotiator in 1995 at the Bosnia peace talks in Dayton, Ohio, he used a mix of high-tech computer mapping and personal charisma to persuade Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian president subsequently indicted for war crimes, to agree to a crucial boundary detail. That helped pave the way for the agreement that ended the bloodiest war in Europe since World War II. 
 But four years later, he showed himself at what his critics call his worst. After General Clark successfully led the 19-member NATO military alliance to victory in Kosovo, he was worried that the Russians might threaten the peacekeeping mission. So he issued an order to use American troops to block a runway to prevent the Russians from flying in reinforcements to an airfield they occupied at Pristina. A British subordinate thought the order so foolhardy and dangerous that he refused to carry it out. 
According to several published accounts, the subordinate, Lt. Gen. Michael Jackson, defiantly told General Clark, "Sir, I'm not starting World War III for you."
These are dual aspects of General Clark, 58, who last week plunged into another kind of theater of combat -- joining nine other candidates for the Democratic nomination for president. They reveal an uncommon potential for leadership but also his unpredictable nature.
It remains to be seen which Wesley Clark will emerge in the campaign ahead. He has no experience on the campaign trail, which is not to say he has no political experience. His fast-track rise to the top of the military, earning his first general's star at the youthful age of 43, attests to his deftness.
"He rose quickly by using his superior intellect and his superior political skills," said Joe Lockhart, who was President Bill Clinton's spokesman at the White House and worked with General Clark. "He's not as much as a neophyte as some would like to paint him."
General Clark's distinguished 32-year active-duty military career is his chief credential for seeking the presidency. It reveals both strengths and shortcomings as it helps to peel back the layers of this man who, for most Americans, is a blank slate.
His career is highlighted by heroics. In Vietnam, he was awarded a Silver Star and Purple Heart, sustaining four wounds while on patrol one day north of Saigon. 
"I have scars all over my body," he said in a recent interview. 
In Bosnia, when an armored vehicle carrying civilian and military colleagues plunged off a rain-swept road near Sarajevo, he tied a rope to a tree and rappelled down the mountainside in an effort to rescue them.
On a lighter note, he demonstrated a flair for raiding enemy territory when he was a cadet at West Point. On Armed Forces Day in 1964, he said, he and some buddies had cadged an invitation to a party in Manhattan for Navy midshipmen. They crashed the party, which is where Cadet Clark met Gertrude Kingston, an executive assistant on Wall Street and his future wife.
His record also reveals a man who is obsessively competitive, with a drive to win at everything he does, no matter how meaningless.
"He is competitive drinking coffee with you," said a senior State Department official.
With that comes a reputation for arrogance, end-running his bosses and what some perceive to be lapses in judgment, some of which nearly derailed his career, according to former senior Pentagon officials.
In one attention-getting episode in 1994, he had been advised by the State Department not to meet with Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian-Serb general accused of slaughtering hundreds of civilians in pursuit of ethnic cleansing. General Clark met with him anyway.
General Mladic gave General Clark a bottle of plum brandy and an inscribed pistol; then the two swapped hats and posed for pictures that were splashed all over Europe. Privately, administration officials fumed that being buddy-buddy with General Mladic was "like cavorting with Hermann Goering." A Pentagon spokesman was left to explain that there must have been "a breakdown in communications."
Even General Clark has acknowledged in interviews and in his memoirs that some in his own service resented him, and at a critical juncture in his military career, his civilian boss, Defense Secretary William J. Perry, had to intervene to keep his career on track. Mr. Perry said in an interview that he had awarded General Clark his fourth star over the Army's favored candidate for the promotion. Mr. Perry, who has already endorsed Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts for president, said of General Clark, "His intellectual horsepower is very impressive."
General Clark was famous for impressing his bosses throughout his career, and yet, at the pinnacle of his power and influence after the Kosovo war, he was cashiered by his boss, William S. Cohen, the secretary of defense, after openly challenging the Clinton administration's reluctance to use ground troops in the conflict.
"I find him to be a guy who's very clever at determining which way the wind's blowing," said Gen. Paul Funk, who was General Clark's boss in the early 1990's. "Who knows, maybe in the political world that's a good thing."
Fred Greenstein, a presidential scholar at Princeton, said that General Clark was in a precarious position as he stepped out on the political stage, in part because he did not yet have a coherent narrative of his life story. "They have to shape the story, and it's not out there," Mr. Greenstein said. "He's got a record that makes him seem potentially like an Eisenhower or a Powell rather than a Schwarzkopf or Patton or one of these people who don't have mainstream appeal. But he somehow needs to bring that to the fore."
What has puzzled some political professionals is that the general's expertise is supposed to be as a military commander, strong on preparation and organization, and yet he does not seem to have a structure or strategy in place for acampaign.
This was immediately evident last week when he announced his candidacy. He did so before hiring a campaign manager and filling other important slots -- and before he seemed to have thought through his positions. This was apparent as he reversed himself on the issue on which was perceived to have the most credibility -- the war in Iraq.
On Thursday, the day after he announced his candidacy, he said, "I probably would have voted for" the resolution. On Friday, he backtracked, saying, "I never would have voted for war." But last October, according to The Associated Press, he said he supported a Congressional resolution to give President Bush authority to use military force against Iraq. He then spent months as a television commentator criticizing the president's action.
That is all the more remarkable given General Clark's history of unfailing preparation for whatever challenge he has taken on and his laser-like determination to achieve since he graduated at the top of his West Point class in 1966 and went to Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar.
During the 1991 Persian Gulf war, for instance, General Clark, then a one-star officer, was in a rear-echelon job as commander of the Army's national training center in the Mojave Desert, a task that included whipping units of the Georgia National Guard into combat shape.
"My job is to get them ready to pass the ultimate test," he said in an interview just before the air war started, dismissing any misgivings that he would be missing out on front-line action in the gulf to train the citizen soldiers.
By the mid-1990's, General Clark had risen to be the chief political-military officer on the military's Joint Staff. In the run-up to the invasion of Haiti in 1994, he insisted that the military plan not only for a worst-case scenario but also for an unopposed entry, which was the eventual outcome. It was a step that State Department officials said most likely prevented bloodshed.
It was in that job that General Clark first appeared on the international stage, when Richard C. Holbrooke tapped him as his top military adviser during the Dayton peace accords in November 1995. In the marathon three-week negotiations that Mr. Holbrooke brokered, General Clark oversaw the drafting of the military chapter of the agreement that gave free rein to a NATO peacekeeping force in Bosnia.
That part of the pact drew criticism from some of General Clark's four-star superiors. But Mr. Holbrooke, who wrote in his book of the tension between General Clark and fellow officers, said in a telephone interview, "Wes ran interference for me with the uniformed services."
After a one-year stint as head of the military's Southern Command, overseeing operations in most of Latin America, General Clark was picked to be the top American commander in Europe and the NATO supreme military chief, one of the most prized jobs in the military.
He seemed perfectly suited for the post, given his experience in the Balkans and his proficiency in Russian. But as he settled into his job, overseeing not only the accord he had help broker for Bosnia but preparing for possible conflict in the Serb province of Kosovo, his strengths also became his weaknesses.
Commanders in Bosnia, and later in Kosovo, complained that General Clark would micromanage from his headquarters in Belgium the tactical details of missions usually left to commanders on the ground.
"It was tenuous at times," said Maj. Gen. David Grange, who is retired now but who headed the First Infantry Division in Bosnia and Kosovo. "He did get into the weeds."
As he struggled to keep the fractious NATO alliance united, he repeatedly clashed with his bosses in Washington -- Mr. Cohen and Gen. Henry H. Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- when he urged the use of American ground troops and Apache attack helicopters after days of bombing alone failed to bring Mr. Milosevic's surrender.
It is unclear how someone so skilled in the political ways of Washington could have put himself in such a precarious position with his civilian masters. Yet when he received word from General Shelton in July 1999 that his command would end earlier than scheduled, General Clark was stunned.
Similarly, despite his months of toying with whether to run for the presidency, he seems ill-prepared. Even if his goal is to be picked as a vice-presidential running mate, he still seems to be short on the fundamentals, like a top-level staff, message and strategy. 
A prominent Democratic fund-raiser said that General Clark seemed bright but that signals from the campaign had not given him confidence.
"You have to worry about a campaign where the theme is so thin that it's based on just 'I can win,' because he's never run before and he's getting an incredibly late start," the fund-raiser said. 
Mr. Lockhart said there was no way to predict how someone, least of all a four-star general, would take to the campaign process. "He's clearly smart enough to do this, he has the communication skills to do this, he has the whole package and the resume," he said. "Now we'll find out whether he can do it."

PROFILE
Wesley Kanne Clark

BORN -- Dec. 23, 1944, Chicago

HOMETOWN -- Little Rock, Ark.

EDUCATION -- Hall High School (Little Rock); B.S., United States Military Academy; master's in philosophy, politics and economics, Oxford University

Clark & Associates, 2002-present.

FAMILY -- Married to Gertrude Kingston; one son

HOBBIES -- Swimming, eating fresh popcorn and listening to Buddy Holly.

HEADLINE: Over The Store 

BYLINE:  By William Norwich; William Norwich is the entertaining editor of The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
It sounded like the most fabulous trip in the world, and I blame my mother. Sleep above arguably the best store in the free world, 10 Corso Como.
 The proprietor, Carla Sozzani, a former business partner of Romeo Gigli and sister of Franca Sozzani, who is the editor of Italian Vogue, opened this hipper-than-thou but user-friendly lifestyle emporium in Milan about 10 years ago. Art gallery, bookshop, courtyard tea garden, restaurant and last, but not least, designer fashion and home boutiques are all rolled into one holistic experience and located in an old, ambient warehouse near the Garibaldi train station. Once a renegade section of Milan, like TriBeCa was in New York, it is now the locus of cool in Italy's slender-hipped style capital. 
 In late spring this year, Sozzani opened a deluxe bed-and-breakfast operation called 3Rooms -- there are just three suites -- in a space she renovated atop the complex. 
Why, you might ask, would a man like me want to sleep over a store when he might do better actualizing himself shooting rapids (doesn't your gun get wet?) on a river through dales and canyons?
Well, we took only one sort of vacation when I was a child: shopping. Your people sought out great museums or anthropological destinations? My people looked for stores. For weekend picnics we went to Loehmann's. During one school holiday when I was 10, we drove from Connecticut to West Virginia to buy crystal at the glass factories near Wheeling. But I regress.
Suffice it to say, I tumbled off an Alitalia flight ultrasteerage early one morning a few weeks ago with great expectations.
"La Vita Moda," the Italian fashion life, I explained to a Milanese friend. Not only was I planning on sleeping above the great boutique, but I was also going to visit the celebrated barber at the Dolce & Gabbana men's store and spa in central Milan, have lunch at Giorgio Armani's restaurant -- he hopes to open a hotel himself soon in the city -- visit Gianfranco Ferre's new spa and, well, get the picture: La Vita Moda.
Hidden behind a discreet facade, 10 Corso Como rises like the promise of new clothes. Alas, when I arrived, it was 9 in the morning, and there was no action, shopping or otherwise. The courtyard was as quiet as the Grand Canyon. A banner from the second-story art gallery announced an exhibition of photographs by Helmut Newton. Smaller signs in the direction of the clothing boutiques whispered, "Soldes," meaning "sales."
"Carla's in Paris," explained a pretty young woman named Katja in snug bluejeans and a white shirt.
Of course, in Paris. (Where she and Azzedine Alaia are opening another 3Rooms at his place in the Marais.) What did I think? That Carla Sozzani actually would be there to greet me, like Aunt Bee in Mayberry?
Katja showed me to my suite, a living room, bedroom, dressing room and bath ready for its close-up in Wallpaper.
All the suites, decorated in a late 1960's modern style, are large and generously appointed with Arne Jacobsen and Eero Saarinen chairs, Kris Ruhs paintings, bedspreads by Charles and Ray Eames and more. And, for tech freaks, the television, music and telephone system is thoroughly modern, Bang & Olufsen. And there is a computer with . . . Internet connections.
Like a spokesman for the world-of-tomorrow exhibition at a World's Fair, Katja deftly demonstrated the many technological delights. 
I, meanwhile, was happy to note there was plenty of room for shopping bags and a full-length mirror in the dressing room, as well as an ironing board and high-tech iron that, according to my limited knowledge of the Italian language, offered cold drinks and Visconti videos.
In other words, I was three days at 3Rooms, and only on the second day did I learn how to turn on the television. On the third day I almost figured out how to turn it off.
Katja left me to unpack and plug in.
Time to go shopping? Not yet. This is what you learn with age: Do not shop when you are hungry, lonely, angry or tired. I came to this realization the expensive way. Back in the early 1990's, off the plane one morning in Paris, half in the bag and severely jet-lagged . . . well, the next thing I knew I was buying an outfit at Jean Paul Gaultier. How did I look? Like Pocahontas.
But by Day 2, I was well rested and ready for full-tilt Vita Moda. I had a relaxed, delicious breakfast in my room. I saw the Helmut Newton exhibition, went to Mr. Armani's cafe for a coffee, had lunch (chicken salad with Parmesan cheese) with friends at Dolce & Gabbana's Martini Bar, got a shave and a buzz cut from Dolce & Gabbana's all-star Sicilian barber, Giovanni Pappalardo, and walked barefoot through Gianfranco Ferre's blue-and-gold tiled spa. Fab-u-lous!
Then I went home and went shopping. Gucci, Helmut Lang, Balenciaga, Viktor & Rolf, Paul Smith, Comme des Garcons -- you name it, I tried it on. Pacing myself still, I settled on a V-neck gunmetal gray Prada sweater at half price.
"May I charge this to my room?" I asked the head clerk.
"No," he answered, and laughed. "But we can deliver it."
Mental note for Carla Sozzani: it might be more fun if the shopping could be billed to your room. After all, the new wave in the hotel business is attracting guests with groovy retail opportunities.
Confronted with a near-savage recession in travel, hotels are pulling out all the stops to attract guests, from fashion boutiques to pampering pets with massages and doggy bathrobes. Telephones at the Carlyle Hotel in New York connect guests to Zitomer's, the madcap boutique pharmacy that sells everything from Xanax to mink teddy bears. The Shore Club in Miami features an outpost of the ultratrendy New York boutique Scoop, which offers Juicy Couture, Marc Jacobs and Jil Sanders, among other labels.
According to Women's Wear Daily, Scoop at the Shore Club, like many hotel boutiques, does a booming business.
"Everybody is on holiday or on vacation," Rachel Kahn, the manager of the Scoop store in Miami, told Women's Wear Daily. "People come in half-naked and leave with a bag full of clothes. When they feel good, it makes for a good business day."
Between my happy patronage and the buzzing machinations of so many shopping Japanese tourists, things were looking pretty good for business at 10 Corso Como.
I carried my Prada purchase to my room -- I needed the exercise -- and returned to the courtyard for dinner. Alone again naturally, sure, but the people-watching was terrific, one Vita Moda Milanese person after another, looking as chic as anyone ever did in an Antonioni film.
Later, I spoke with Carla Sozzani on the phone. "So this is La Vita Moda," I said.
"Is it? Shopping was not my only idea," she said. Famously serene and mellow, Carla explained: "But I live with fashion, so it's another story maybe? I don't know. My idea was just to expand what I hope we have at 10 Corso Como, a place where people can come and feel at home."
I told her that a lot like at home, I was unable to get anything electronic to work. Blame it on the jet lag?
Carla laughed.
"Next time we'll get you a tutor."
Wow, a blind date. Now that is fine hotel service.
Rooms at the hotel are not cheap. About 520 euros (around $570) a night. This is about the starting price for a double room at the Principe di Savoia and about $110 less than the same at the Four Seasons in Milan.
Who will stay here? 
3Rooms will appeal to well-heeled hipsters not in a rush. Terry Jones, the editor of i-D magazine and the father of the photographer Matt Jones, stayed at the bed-and-breakfast this summer. The photographer David LaChapelle checked into a suite for nearly two weeks.
"Then there was a woman," Carla said, "a German lady. She checked in in the morning. Went shopping until 9 that night. Ate. And left the next morning. You would have liked her."
Liked her? We're probably related. 

TRAVELING LA VITA MODA
Long gone are the days when people competed to look chic when they traveled. But certainly a status signifier or two can make a trip more luxe.
Keep time on both sides of the Atlantic with the Hermes Cape Cod Dual Time Zone Watch (1), $1,700. At Hermes boutiques nationwide. Call home with Vertu's Bordeaux Stainless Steel World Phone (2), $6,000. Go to www.vertu.com. Drown out unwanted sound with the Bose Quietcomfort 2 Acoustic Noise-Canceling Headphones (3), $299.
