An article yesterday about Secretary General Kofi Annan's speech to the United Nations General Assembly quoted incorrectly from a remark he made about the organization's failure to include more developing countries in the Security Council after more than a decade of debate. Mr. Annan told the delegates that unless they address the issue with greater urgency, history "will not forgive us" (not "forget us").

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET --Long Island; 
A Big REIT Is Taking A New Tack

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

DATELINE: MELVILLE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Members of the family that founded the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, the Long Island-based real estate investment trust with more than 20 million square feet of office and industrial space in the New York area, are in the process of taking part of their properties private in a $315 million transaction.
 Four members of the Rechler family will resign from the REIT to acquire its Long Island industrial portfolio, with properties totaling 5.9 million square feet. They will form Rechler Equity Partners in a deal that is expected to close by the end of the year. The family entered the real estate business 42 years ago, and Reckson went public in 1995. 
 The planned acquisition will cover 95 properties, with 300,000 square feet in Nassau County and 5.6 million in Suffolk County.
 The transaction will ensure that the Rechler family remains the largest holder of properties in Long Island's strong industrial market, according to Jack O'Connor, senior vice president at the Woodbury office of CB Richard Ellis, the real estate services company.
 "This particular venture will not have an impact on the office market," Mr. O'Connor said. But he estimated that the new company's plans to buy up and renovate vacant industrial buildings could reduce the industrial vacancy rate by "up to three-quarters" of a percentage point. The vacancy rate is currently 6.3 percent. 
 "Long Island's industrial marketplace remains strong," Mr. O'Connor added, "primarily because of our diversification; we are not impacted by a national recession. The Rechlers are known for quality buildings and will be a major player and a lure for national companies as they renovate old buildings and look to acquire more land."
 Active family members today are Donald Rechler and his son Mitchell and Roger Rechler and his sons Scott and Gregg. 
 Scott Rechler will remain the REIT's chief executive, a position he now shares with Donald Rechler, who will remain as Reckson's nonexecutive chairman while joining the others as a partner in the new industrial company.
 Mitchell and Gregg Rechler are currently Reckson's chief administrative and operating officers. They will be the managing partners of Rechler Equity Partners and will remain with the REIT in an advisory capacity for two years. 
 Explaining some of the thinking behind the split in an interview at Reckson's headquarters, Mitchell Rechler said: "Going private allows us more flexibility to dedicate our time to doing what we like most, getting our hands on the real estate. With the REIT, 50 percent of our time was dealing with the public end. Also, we were managing 330 employees under Reckson; now we will have 30." 
 In a telephone interview, Scott Rechler said, "We had always planned that as the company grew to a certain size we would be grooming a management team to grow as well that could fill the role of some of the family." 
 There were also estate planning considerations for family members, he said.
 The Rechler family's ties to the industrial portfolio go back to 1961 when William Rechler, who died in 1976, came to Long Island from the Bronx and purchased 1,400 acres of land that would become part of the Hauppauge Industrial Park. In 1968, his sons Donald and Roger founded Reckson Associates.
 Its first project that year was a 12,000-square-foot industrial building in Islandia that cost $5.50 a square foot to develop. 
 When Reckson went public in 1995, its industrial properties and most of its office properties were rolled into the REIT, which became the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation. 
 When the company went public, its common shares sold for $12.13 a share, adjusted for splits, and it had a total market capitalization of about $400 million. Today, the shares are trading around $23 a share and the company's market capitalization is in excess of $3 billion.
 Reckson's most recent industrial project, a 70,000-square-foot building completed this year, was the final structure in a four-building complex of ultramodern Class A high-tech industrial buildings totaling 540,000 square feet at Airport International Plaza in Bohemia. 
 Its most recent office acquisition was the $31 million purchase last month of a 180,000-square-foot building at 1055 Washington Boulevard in downtown Stamford, Conn. 
 The REIT will retain about 500,000 square feet of industrial properties in Westchester County, New Jersey and Connecticut, as well as its 14.8 million square feet of office buildings. Of the office portfolio, 34 percent is in Manhattan, 28 percent in Westchester and Connecticut, 16 percent in New Jersey and 22 percent in Long Island.
 "We wanted to take the proceeds from the sale of the industrial properties and continue to grow and have a balance in all markets,"said Scott Rechler. 
 According to Mitchell and Gregg Rechler, the new industrial company plans to build up its portfolio by redeveloping property, including 2.5 million square feet at the 14-million-square-foot Hauppauge Industrial Park. 
 "We plan to convert the older buildings that our grandfather built and redevelop them into high-tech industrial and office space, and we will aggressively pursue new properties," Gregg Rechler said.

HEADLINE: Cut the Cost of Prescription Drugs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What is particularly outrageous about the drug industry's opposition to the importation of Canadian drugs is the repeated rationale that the United States market provides the resources for necessary research (editorial, Sept. 20). 
Where is it written that only Americans should pay for drug research?
 Since most workers receive their drugs through an employer plan with only a small co-payment, the only people in the world who pay full price for their medications are the elderly, employees who are not covered by their employers or, even worse, the unemployed and the disabled. 
 Is this the way to pay for research, particularly since so much of it is done by the United States government at taxpayer expense?
The pharmaceutical industry can get away with this only as long as it continues to line the pockets of our representatives and senators from both political parties.

CLARA C. WOLL
New Hyde Park, N.Y., Sept. 20, 2003

HEADLINE: Learning From 9/11, Bloomberg Seeks High-Rise Safety Changes 

BYLINE:  By MIKE McINTIRE

 BODY:
Legislation that would enact most of the fire safety improvements for tall buildings recommended by a task force that studied the World Trade Center collapse was announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
 Under a bill being submitted to the City Council next week, existing office towers in New York would have to comply with some of the stricter codes already in place for new buildings, including a potentially expensive requirement that sprinkler systems be installed. 
 City officials estimated that 200 to 400 buildings, all more than 9 or 10 stories tall, would need to be retro-fitted with sprinklers. 
Building owners would have 15 years to put the systems in place. They could apply for an extension in cases of financial hardship or waivers where structural limitations or historic-landmark status made them impractical. Mr. Bloomberg acknowledged that economic concerns drove the decision to set a lengthy deadline for compliance.
"It sounds like a long time," the mayor said at a City Hall news conference. "But in a practical sense, by the time everything is engineered and given the economic expense, we think it is a reasonable compromise between our needs to get these buildings sprinklered and what landlords can afford."
Landlords would have much less time -- generally 18 months -- to comply with other proposals, which include adding more illuminated exit signs, providing backup power to existingsigns and placing glow-in-the-dark markings in stairwells.
Most of the legislation affects construction of new commercial buildings and is a result of lessons learned from the trade center disaster. For instance, buildings will be required to have stronger steel joists, since investigators believe the "open web" joists used in the trade center design failed more quickly in the extreme heat caused by jet-fuel fires.
Also, stairwells must be made more resistant to impacts; collapsing drywall stairwell enclosures were blamed for blocking the exits for many people trapped in the twin towers.
Over all, the proposals are geared toward giving office workers more time to escape.
"We can make buildings safer by getting people out faster," said Barbara J. Lancaster, the city building commissioner.
The 13 proposals in the legislation are drawn from a report released in February by the Building Department's World Trade Center building code task force. The report contained 21 recommendations, two of which have already been enacted. Six more are still under technical review, Ms. Lancaster said.
The legislation will be taken up by the Council's Housing and Buildings Committee, whose chairwoman, Madeline Provenzano, joined the mayor in issuing a statement yesterday praising the task force's work.
The task force included a representative of the Real Estate Board of New York, which in the past lobbied against requiring sprinkler systems in existing buildings. This time, the board lined up behind the recommendation, despite lingering concerns that the 15-year window for compliance "may actually not be enough time," said Marilyn Davenport, the board's senior vice president.
"We support the legislation," Ms. Davenport said. "There will be a cost involved, but we think it's the right thing to do."

HEADLINE: First Wave Of Suits Hits Mutual Funds Under Inquiry 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The lawyers who have filed hundreds of claims against investment banks, research analysts and corporate executives are now training their guns on mutual funds.
 Nearly a dozen plaintiff law firms have brought lawsuits against companies that manage mutual funds in the three weeks since Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, accused some fund companies of allowing favored investors to engage in trades not possible for most shareholders. Bank One, Strong Capital Management, Bank of America and Janus have been named in the suits, as they were by Mr. Spitzer. 
 But Mr. Spitzer, who has already received one big settlement from Wall Street, has said that the problem is more widespread and that his investigation is widening. The plaintiffs' lawyers are eagerly watching and are even trying to identify the firms that have received subpoenas. 
"Any time you introduce big, sophisticated players essentially engaging in what seems like preferential treatment and small investors being the worse off for it, that creates, potentially, a big claim," said Michael A. Perino, a professor at St. John's University School of Law in New York. 
The reason is simple. Investment companies, which manage some $7 trillion invested by 95 million Americans, are plump targets.
Plaintiffs' lawyers hope that the funds will ultimately settle, partly because of the difficulty of defending themselves in numerous cases. So far, the fund companies' public statements have not denied engaging in questionable practices and have, in some cases, vowed to make restitution where appropriate.
The lawsuits challenge the practices identified by Mr. Spitzer and federal regulators. Those practices include allowing favored investors to trade after hours and to buy and sell mutual fund shares over short periods to turn a quick profit, a practice known as timing.
In the eyes of plaintiffs' lawyers, the potential settlements could dwarf the biggest paid by corporate defendants (and their insurers) in shareholder lawsuits to date -- for example, $3.5 billion to settle claims of fraud at the Cendant Corporation and $568 million to settle claims that executives at Lucent misled investors.
Wall Street firms, after agreeing to pay $1 billion to settle regulators' complaints about research and conflicts, are still battling shareholder suits, and the cost is hard to gauge. In June some 300 companies agreed to pay $1 billion to escape litigation that challenged practices in initial stock offerings.
The suits against mutual fund companies rely on laws governing that industry, rather than those used in most shareholder suits. This lets lawyers skirt hurdles from legislation in the mid-1990's that make it harder to bring securities suits as class actions in federal court.
"It's not a traditional case," said Seth Ottensosser, a lawyer at the New York firm of Bernstein Liebhard & Lifshitz, which has filed five lawsuits so far, against Janus, Strong and Bank One. "We always have to be innovative."
Because the legal arguments are novel, Mr. Perino said, predicting the outcome of the lawsuits is hard. "Whether this turns into a big payday at the end of the day is still an open question."
Even if the suits are ultimately unsuccessful, battling them will cost time and money, said Aegis J. Frumento, head of the securities litigation group at Duane Morris. 
"Lawsuits are headaches by definition," Mr. Frumento said. "Certainly, the plaintiffs bar is very creative, they're very imaginative and they're very aggressive."
The fund companies have declined to comment on the shareholder suits. But in public statements, Janus, Bank One and Strong have advised shareholders that they are conducting investigations into their practices in response to Mr. Spitzer's concerns. Bank One and Janus also say that if appropriate, they will make restitution to investors. 
Mr. Ottensosser's firm, like numerous other plaintiff-side firms, is busily investigating several mutual funds. It has a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a former New York City police detective and a former investigative reporter interviewing investors, former employees of fund managers and others, Mr. Ottensosser said.
It is easier and cheaper, though, to use information made public by Mr. Spitzer and federal regulators to identify funds that are worth a closer look, said Mr. Perino, the law professor. "Here, the state attorney general's office has basically done the work for you."
Another benefit for lawyers suing mutual funds is the ability to draw on laws other than the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which usually form the basis for shareholder lawsuits against companies and their executives, Mr. Perino said. Laws passed in the 1990's require such lawsuits to meet tougher standards, such as describing in detail any suspected fraud before the lawyers have begun discovery. Those standards do not apply, however, to suits brought under two other laws that apply to mutual funds, the Investment Company Act and the Investment Advisers Act, both of 1940.
"Potentially, it's a great opportunity for plaintiffs' lawyers because it puts them back to where they were on Dec. 21, 1995," before the laws imposing the tougher standards were passed, Mr. Perino said.
But the plaintiffs' lawyers will still face obstacles, said Fred Dunbar, a senior vice president at NERA Economic Consulting who has been an expert witness in calculating damages in securities lawsuits. 
First, market timing is not easily defined, he said. Second, establishing liability may be hard, because market timing is not always illegal and because some investors who traded in and out of funds quickly did not intend to engage in market timing. 
Even if liability is established, calculating damages is not easy because there will probably not be an agreed-upon method of valuing fund shares and adjusting for one investor's market timing, Mr. Dunbar said.
Steven G. Schulman, a partner in the New York office of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, said it was too early to calculate damages."It's clear that value has been diverted from the funds," said Mr. Schulman, whose firm has filed 8 to 10 lawsuits so far. As for damages, he said, "That's a question of fact for trial."

HEADLINE: Hearing on E.P.A. Nominee Takes an Ideological Turn 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Senate Democrats used the confirmation hearing today on Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, President Bush's choice for administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, as a forum to sharply criticize the administration's environmental record, all but ignoring the nominee sitting in front of them.
 In the packed, three-hour hearing, members of the Environment and Public Works Committee told Mr. Leavitt repeatedly that the job he was seeking was one of the worst in Washington. 
 In response, Mr. Leavitt said that he viewed himself as a problem solver, that his preferred approach was collaboration and that his main goal was clean air.
"The solutions to these problems are found in the productive middle," he said. "Rarely are they found at the extremes."
Democrats and Republicans expect the committee to confirm Mr. Leavitt when it meets next week and say that the full Senate will vote to confirm him.
But four Democratic senators -- Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and three who are running for president: John Kerry of Massachusetts, Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and John Edwards of North Carolina -- have said they will bar the nomination from reaching the Senate until President Bush addressed certain issues. These include questions about why the administration removed warnings from agency press releases about the safety of the air at ground zero in New York shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
Republican aides said after the hearing that the White House was likely to work out these issues with each senator.
Even environmentalists who oppose the nomination predicted that Mr. Leavitt would be confirmed.
"In the long run, the odds are that Governor Leavitt will be confirmed, but not without some significant compromises from the administration," largely on providing information that committee members have sought, said Philip E. Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust.
In the hearing, Mr. Leavitt revealed little about his intentions as administrator and made no commitments.
Swirling around him were accusations from Democrats that the Bush administration's record on the environment had been a disaster and that the administration could not be trusted on the issue. Mr. Leavitt faced almost no questions about his 11-year record as governor.
In his opening remarks, Senator James M. Inhofe, the Oklahoma Republican who is chairman of the committee, predicted that the hearing would be less about Mr. Leavitt than it would be a battleground over Mr. Bush's environmental record. Mr. Inhofe recited objections raised by environmentalists about the president's policies -- chiefly, that he was a friend to polluters -- and said none of them were true.
Mr. Leavitt refused to be drawn in to that debate.
To a request from Senator James M. Jeffords, the Vermont independent, for information on a recent administration decision not to require pollution-control devices on old power plants, he answered, "My objective is to have the air cleaner when I finish than when I started."
When Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, asked Mr. Leavitt if he would freeze that rule, noting that the governor's own director of air quality in Utah had strenuously objected to it, he said that the official had changed his mind and no longer objected.
The Republican members of the committee reproached the Democrats for what they said were baseless accusations about administration policies. Mr. Inhofe said at one point that the concept of global warming, a concern of the Democrats, "could be the greatest hoax ever perpetrated on the American people."
Some senators portrayed Mr. Leavitt as bystander tossed into the Cuisinart of partisan Washington politics.
"Into this political cauldron comes a good man," Mr. Wyden said.
Senators from each party expressed befuddlement over why Mr. Leavitt sought the job, particularly given the interagency tensions that preceded the resignation of the previous administrator, Christie Whitman, a Republican.
Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, said that Ms. Whitman "did the very best she could, but I'm sure she was relieved and glad to leave the battle."
Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, told Mr. Leavitt, "Governor, you've got a lot of guts to take this job," adding that it would probably be impossible to override the White House if he ever thought the president was wrong. "The fact that you decided to take this job in no way is impugning your intelligence," Mr. Reid assured him.
And Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, warned him that he would be giving up control by leaving the governor's office. "I've seen so many governors come here and think they could run it the way they ran their states," Mr. Baucus said. But Washington is different, he said, because "you're someplace else in the pecking order" and in Washington, the knives are longer.
Mr. Leavitt said that in seeking the post, he was answering the president's call.
"I passionately believe that this nation deserves to have a clean and safe and healthy environment," he said. "And I also believe that the United States can increase our velocity of our environmental progress. We can do it without compromising our competitive position economically in the world."
After the hearing, Mr. Leavitt told reporters who asked whether he was being naive about the difficulties of the job: "I don't have any illusions that it's an easy job. The president's asked that I do it, and I am going to give every ounce of energy I have."

HEADLINE: Schwarzenegger Learning His Lines, and Others', for Debate Tonight 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
As Arnold Schwarzenegger prepared for his first and only debate, his handlers said they expected few specifics from any participant.
 Mr. Schwarzenegger, who contrary to his public image says he has laid out the most specific agenda of any of the recall candidates, is preparing for a full frontal assault from the four candidates who will share the stage with him on Wednesday at Sacramento State University for the 90-minute debate. 
 With questions (for instance: What does a colorblind society mean to you?) already distributed to the candidates, those prepping Mr. Schwarzenegger said he was expecting trickery from Tom McClintock, the conservative state senator who is splitting the Republican vote with him and who is coming under heavy pressure from the establishment right to drop out. Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante, the main Democrat on the recall ballot, leads Mr. Schwarzenegger in the most recent poll by 2 percentage points and Mr. McClintock by 14. 
"We expect Tom to throw long, try silly stunts, do something to distinguish himself," an aide to Mr. Schwarzenegger said. "We expect him to ask for a no-tax pledge or challenge him to another debate. Arnold will be prepared to answer."
Mr. Schwarzenegger's strategy will be to raise the specter of special-interest money, which has flooded the Bustamante campaign and to a lesser extent Mr. McClintock's, the aide said. The Schwarzenegger strategy is to make a boogeyman of the Indian tribes who have contributed generously to his opponents.
On Monday, a county judge ruled that Mr. Bustamante illegally used millions of dollars donated to him by big tribes and big labor. The judge ordered the campaign to return nearly $4 million. Commercials valued at $500,000 that feature Mr. McClintock as the best choice for California were paid for by another powerful gambling tribe. 
As for Ariana Huffington, the radio personality and author who is campaigning as an alternative to corporate greed, Mr. Schwarzenegger may remind her on the stage that she paid less than $800 in income taxes over a two-year period and took enormous write-offs through her company, the Schwarzenegger aide said. Mr. Schwarzenegger will characterize Peter Camejo, the Green Party candidate, as a reckless tax-and-spend zealot.
Now that the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has reversed itself, full attention is focused on Wednesday's debate, which is seen as critical to the chances of Mr. Schwarzenegger and Mr. Bustamante for replacing Gov. Gray Davis.
In a recent poll by the Public Policy Institute of California, 67 percent of likely voters said the performance of the candidates in the debate would weigh significantly in their decisions. The poll shows that Mr. Bustamante's support is eroding while Mr. Schwarzenegger's has stagnated as he fights the perception that his campaign has little substance. 
But some politicians and political writers believe that Mr. Schwarzenegger has offered the most detailed plans of any of the major candidates. Drowned out in the off-again-on-again rulings by the court of appeals this last week were two major initiatives he laid out.
Last week, he offered a four-point plan to make state government more transparent, including a fund-raising freeze during the budget season to lock out big-money influence. He also called for increased penalties for fund-raising violations for the kinds of irregularities the county court said Mr. Bustamante committed.
On Sunday, Mr. Schwarzenegger unveiled an ambitious environmental plan that would end offshore oil drilling, build a network of hydrogen fueling stations and force older polluting vehicles off the roads. Even so, Mr. Schwarzenegger was criticized for his role as a spokesman for the Hummer military-style vehicle.
"It's the most advanced environmental program offered by a serious contender for governor," said William Bradley, a former California Democratic political adviser.
The other candidates have offered few nuggets of specificity, and when they have, economic and political professionals have criticized them as wishful or unrealistic. Mr. Bustamante has proposed $8 billion in tax increases despite the fact that Republicans refused to raise them a nickel during the last budget negotiations. He has proposed a $500 million savings by rooting out MediCal insurance corruption, which he acknowledges goes on under his watch. He also proposes $2 billion in other unspecified savings.
Mr. McClintock, like Mr. Schwarzenegger, proposes rolling back the $4 billion tax increase for car registration fees, but he has not said where he would find the money to replace it in the budget. He also said he would rescind the energy contracts signed by Mr. Davis at the height of the power crisis, despite the fact that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has ruled that those contracts stand.
"Everyone is being vague, it's true," said Aaron S. Edlin, a professor of law and economics at the University of California at Berkeley. "Bustamante has a plan that is arithmetically possible but politically unpopular. Schwarzenegger's is arithmetically impossible and McClintock's is arithmetically impossible and probably irrelevant."
A bit of momentum is swinging toward Gray Davis, with just 53 percent of likely voters in favor of a recall, compared with 58 percent a month ago. To combat this, Mr. Schwarzenegger has begun an advertising blitz reminding citizens that Mr. Davis signed bad energy contracts, gave driver's licenses to illegal immigrants and raised the car tax 300 percent.
"The spotlight has illuminated the paucity of substance," said Jerry Brown, former governor of California and current mayor of Oakland. "They're all praying the economy gets better and the deficit disappears."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: COSTS; 
Partisan Battle Builds in Congress Over Bush's Spending Request

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
The huge sums requested by the White House to occupy and rebuild Iraq sharply inflamed partisan tensions on Capitol Hill today, with Republican leaders accusing Democrats of undermining the military and sowing division by criticizing the Bush administration's postwar policies. 
 Democrats, emboldened by internal polls showing a growing public unease with the administration's $87 billion spending request for military and reconstruction efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan, have strongly amplified their disagreements with the White House in recent days. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who said late last week that President Bush's Iraq policy was a "fraud," today went to the Senate floor to describe the policy as a "colossal failure" unworthy of what he said was an $87 billion blank check. 
 Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said the $20.3 billion the president wanted for reconstruction in Iraq alone would have a hard time passing without a stronger justification. 
Republican lawmakers lashed back in their strongest terms yet. Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House Republican leader, accused Mr. Kennedy of uttering "hate speech" and said he needed to apologize to the country for accusing Mr. Bush of what amounted to treason. Senate leaders said the criticism threatened the military's mission.
"Those comments, while freely exercised in freedom of speech, they strike at the hearts of the military families," said Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, referring specifically to Mr. Kennedy.
"The impact that has on our ability to maintain a strong and viable armed forces -- I think some of those comments have no place in the dialogue of the Congress of the United States," Mr. Warner added.
The increasingly harsh words among lawmakers do not necessarily reflect the degree of support for the Iraq spending bill, which large majorities of both parties say they will approve after several weeks of hearings and questioning.
Rather, the $87 billion request has become a surrogate for the longstanding political divisions between the two parties. By contrasting the amounts allotted for schools, hospitals and roads in Iraq, for example, while infrastructure is crumbling at home, Democrats are really making a case against Mr. Bush's tax cuts and economic policies at home.
Many Republicans, at the same time, share the unease over the size of the request, but say they have to support the president when polls show his approval levels declining.
"You have to admit with some members there was sticker shock at $87 billion," Mr. DeLay said. "They're trying to grapple with that."
A memorandum distributed to Congressional Democrats by Democracy Corps, an opinion research firm run by several former members of the Clinton administration, said that 60 percent of the public opposes the $87 billion request, while 54 percent believe Mr. Bush does not have a plan to win the peace and bring troops home.
The memorandum, by John Podesta, President Bill Clinton's chief of staff, and Stanley B. Greenberg, his pollster, urges Democrats to wage a battle over the spending request as a way of framing the public debate.
Bolstered by these numbers, Democrats are growing vocal about the costs of Iraq. House Democrats released a study today asserting that the long-term cost of remaining in Iraq would be much greater than the administration has said -- $237 billion if troops remain through 2006, and $309 billion if troops remain through 2008. 
Mr. Daschle said that if the $20.3 billion in reconstruction money could be broken out from the military part of the request and voted on separately -- a plan already rejected by Republicans -- it would not pass the Senate.
And Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, forcefully rejected the argument of L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator of Iraq, that the money must be spent quickly to avoid further unrest there.
"Every time I hear in the administration, 'If you don't do this immediately, dire consequence are going to follow,' we do things immediately and dire consequences follow," Mr. Hoyer said. "I am not very sanguine about Mr. Bremer or the administration's representations, which have proved to be egregiously incorrect for the most part."
Mr. Bremer testified on Monday that the money would provide only the most fundamental and essential services for Iraq. But even Republican officials said they were surprised by the breadth of the public works projects the administration was proposing. One Republican official noted with amazement that amid all the housing and water projects was $19 million to build a wireless Internet network for the Iraqi post office that mobile computer users could join.
Publicly, however, Republicans made it clear that their defense to the charge of excessive generosity to Iraq would be a vigorous comparison to the Marshall Plan that rebuilt Europe after World War II.
"After World War II we built schools and roads and hospitals in Japan and in Germany when we did not have those things in Tennessee," said Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee. "And we did it not for the Japanese and the Germans, but for ourselves, because we knew we had to win the peace as well as win the war. I think the people of Tennessee understand that we can't just walk away from this mess."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ; 
In Annan and Chirac's Words: 'Fork in the Road' and 'Call a Summit'

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from speeches today at the General Assembly by Secretary General Kofi Annan and President Jacques Chirac of France, as supplied, partly in translation, by the United Nations. The texts are at www .nytimes.com/international.

By Kofi Annan
 The last 12 months have been very painful for those of us who believe in collective answers to our common problems and challenges. In many countries, terrorism has once again brought death and suffering to innocent people. In the Middle East and in certain parts of Africa, violence has continued to escalate. In the Korean Peninsula and elsewhere, the threat of nuclear proliferation casts an ominous shadow across the landscape. 
 And barely one month ago in Baghdad, the United Nations itself suffered a brutal and deliberate assault in which the international community lost some of its most talented servants. Yesterday it was attacked again. . . . 
Excellencies, you are the United Nations. The staff who were killed and injured in the attack on our Baghdad headquarters were your staff. You had given them a mandate to assist the suffering Iraqi people and to help Iraq recover their sovereignty. In future, not only in Iraq but wherever the United Nations is engaged, we must take more effective measures to protect the security of our staff. . . . 
Subject to security considerations, the United Nations system is prepared to play its full role in working for a satisfactory outcome in Iraq and to do so as part of an international effort, an effort by the whole international community, pulling together on the basis of a sound and viable policy. 
If it takes extra time and patience to forge that policy, a policy that is collective, coherent and workable, then I for one would regard that time as well spent. Indeed, this is how we must approach all the many pressing crises that confront us today.
Excellencies, three years ago, when you came here for the Millennium Summit, we shared a vision, a vision of global solidarity and collective security, expressed in the Millennium Declaration. But recent events have called that consensus in question.
All of us know there are new threats that must be faced or, perhaps, old threats in new and dangerous combinations, new forms of terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
But while some consider these threats as self-evidently the main challenge to world peace and security, others feel more immediately menaced by small arms employed in civil conflict or by so-called soft threats such as the persistence of extreme poverty, the disparity of income between and within societies, and the spread of infectious diseases, or climate change and environmental degradation.
In truth, we do not have to choose. The United Nations must confront all these threats and challenges, new and old, hard and soft. . . . In fact, all these struggles are linked. We now see, with chilling clarity, that a world where many millions of people endure brutal oppression and extreme misery will never be fully secure, even for its most privileged inhabitants. 
Yet the hard threats such as terrorism and weapons of mass destruction are real and cannot be ignored. Terrorism is not a problem only for rich countries. Ask the people of Bali or Bombay, Nairobi or Casablanca. Weapons of mass destruction do not threaten only the western or northern world. Ask the people of Iran or of Halabja in Iraq.
Where we disagree, it seems, is on how to respond to these threats. Since this organization was founded, states have generally sought to deal with threats to the peace through containment and deterrence, by a system based on collective security and the United Nations Charter.
Article 51 of the Charter prescribes that all states, if attacked, retain the inherent right of self-defense. But until now, it has been understood that when states go beyond that and decide to use force to deal with broader threats to international peace and security, they need the unique legitimacy provided by the United Nations.
Now some say this understanding is no longer tenable, since an armed attack with weapons of mass destruction could be launched at any time without warning or by a clandestine group. Rather than wait for that to happen, they argue, states have the right and obligation to use force pre-emptively. . . . It is not enough to denounce unilateralism, unless we also face up squarely to the concerns that make some states feel uniquely vulnerable, since it is those concerns that drive them to take unilateral action. We must show that those concerns can, and will, be addressed effectively through collective action.
Excellencies, we have come to a fork in the road. This may be a moment no less decisive than 1945 itself, when the United Nations was founded. . . . 
The Council needs to consider how it will deal with the possibility that individual states may use force pre-emptively against perceived threats. Its members may need to begin a discussion on the criteria for an early authorization of coercive measures to address certain types of threats, for instance, terrorist groups armed with weapons of mass destruction. And they still need to engage in serious discussions of the best way to respond to threats of genocide or other comparable massive violations of human rights, an issue which I raised myself from this podium in 1999. Once again this year, our collective response to events of this type in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and in Liberia has been hesitant and tardy.

By Jacques Chirac
The United Nations has just weathered one of the gravest trials in its history. The debate turned on respect for the Charter and the use of force. The war, embarked on without Security Council approval, has undermined the multilateral system.
Having taken stock of this crisis, our organization can now resume its onward march. For it is above all in this forum, which is the crucible of the international order, that it behooves us to exercise our responsibilities to the world of today and to future generations. . . . 
Multilateralism is the key, for it ensures the participation of all in the management of world affairs. It is a guarantee of legitimacy and democracy, especially in matters regarding the use of force or laying down universal norms. . . . 
In Iraq, the transfer of sovereignty to the Iraqis, who must have sole responsibility for their future, is essential for stability and reconstruction. It is up to the United Nations to give legitimacy to this process. 
It is also up to the United Nations to assist with the gradual transfer of administrative and economic responsibilities to the present Iraqi institutions according to a realistic timetable and to help the Iraqis draft a constitution and hold elections. 
Lastly, it is up to the United Nations to give a mandate to a multinational force, commanded naturally by the main troop contributor, in order to ensure the security of Iraq and all those helping with the country's reconstruction.
In this way, the international community and the Iraqi people, united around a common project, will together end the tragic decades of this great country's history. . . . 
The fight against international terrorism is another key challenge. This is well in hand, under Security Council auspices and within the framework of our various treaties. 
Our determination is rooted in the horror of Sept. 11. The threat goes to the very heart of our democracies and societies. We are using force to combat terrorism, but that is not enough. It will return over and over if we allow extremism and fanaticism to flourish, if we fail to realize that it uses the world's unresolved conflicts and imbalances as its justification.
In the face of proliferating weapons of mass destruction, we reject all faits accomplis. 
We must stand united in ensuring the universality of treaties and the effectiveness of nonproliferation regimes. We must strengthen our means of action in order to ensure compliance. 
France has proposed the creation of a permanent corps of inspectors under the authority of the Security Council. We need to give fresh impetus to this policy. Let us call a summit meeting of the Security Council to frame a genuine United Nations action plan against proliferation. . . . 
In order to fulfill the missions entrusted to it and remedy some of its blatant shortcomings, the United Nations must change. Democracy, authority and efficacy must be our watchwords. Progress has been made, thanks to the secretary general, and new avenues are opening up. It is now up to the member states to take matters forward without delay and to put an end to the damage caused by the stalemate over reforms.
The United Nations suffers from the current weakness of the General Assembly. Yet that is where debate on solutions to the world's great problems should take place and consensus be forged. A culture of confrontation must give way to a culture of action, aimed at achieving our common goals.
Chief responsibility for the maintenance of peace and security lies with the Security Council. It is therefore essential to its legitimacy that its membership reflect the state of the world. It must be enlarged to include new permanent members, for it needs the presence of major countries. France is thinking, naturally, of Germany and Japan, but also of some leading countries from Asia, Africa and Latin America. It needs additional elected countries, as well, in order to make the Council more representative still. . . . This reform should be accompanied by a strengthening of the Council's authority. 
It is the role of the Council to set the bounds to the use of force. No one is entitled to arrogate to himself the right to utilize it unilaterally and preventively.
Conversely, in the face of mounting threats, states must have an assurance that the Council has appropriate means of evaluation and collective action at its disposal, and that it has the will to act. . . . 
Ladies and gentlemen, against the risk of a world without order delivered up to violence, let us work to establish one governed by the rule of law.
Against the injustice and suffering of a world of ever-widening inequalities -- even though it has never been as rich as it is today -- let us choose solidarity.
Against the chaos of a world shaken by ecological disaster, let us call for a sharing of responsibility, around a United Nations Environmental Organization.
Against the barbarity of a world in which fundamental rights are trampled on, where the integrity of mankind is under threat, where native peoples -- the heirs to an irreplaceable heritage -- vanish amid silence and indifference, let us uphold the demands of ethics.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Jacques Chirac of France at U.N. (Photo by Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dean Takes The Offensive In Comments On Clark 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN with EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Howard Dean, whose campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has been built on an antiwar message, yesterday questioned the antiwar credentials of his newest opponent, Gen. Wesley K. Clark.
 Dr. Dean, who himself has been accused by rivals of flip-flopping on issues, focused on remarks General Clark made last week when, in interviews, he first said that he probably would have voted for the Congressional resolution authorizing war in Iraq and then, the following day, was led to backtrack. 
 "I was shocked" by General Clark's initial comment on the resolution, Dr. Dean, former governor of Vermont, said in an interview as he flew from a rally in Boston to a series of fund-raisers in New York. "I was even more shocked that he switched the next day."
"He still has to clarify his position," the candidate added.
Dr. Dean, who had met several times with General Clark to discuss national security, spoke after a week in which the retired NATO commander's entry into the crowded race largely eclipsed the former governor's summer surge.
Though raising questions about his new rival, Dr. Dean largely stuck yesterday to the tactics that had attracted a great deal of support, intensifying his attack on President Bush. He drew laughs from a noontime crowd of about 3,000 at Copley Square in Boston when he said that before the American Revolution, "there was a king named George who had forgotten his own people in favor of special interests."
"What's at stake in this election is democracy itself," he said. "James Madison and Thomas Jefferson spoke of the fear that economic power would one day seize political power. That fear has been realized in this administration."
Dr. Dean used the language of the Constitution's preamble to condemn the president's record on court appointments, race, education, domestic security and the war on terrorism. "This democracy and the flag of the United States," he then said, "do not belong to Rush Limbaugh and Jerry Falwell and Tom DeLay and John Ashcroft and Dick Cheney."
Though in the home state of a second Democratic rival, Senator John Kerry, he made no mention of him.
The speech followed suggestions by three national polls that after a week of saturation news coverage, General Clark had moved at least for now to the top of the 10-member Democratic presidential field.
For his part, the general focused yesterday on Mr. Bush and Iraq.
"I've been against the war from the beginning," he told reporters in Indiana, where he later addressed students at DePauw University.
"I never saw the imminent threat in Iraq, and I think the president failed to really make the case of the imminent threat," he said. "I think the facts on the ground show there wasn't an imminent threat, and I think this is the whole undercurrent which has made it so difficult for him to receive the kind of assistance he and we would like to have from the international community."
Then, in his visit to DePauw last night, General Clark told students that the United States needed "a new strategy for dealing with the world and a new strategy at home." He also said his young campaign had already raised $1 million.
If General Clark's candidacy took the harsh spotlight off Dr. Dean last week, the onetime governor has continued to be a chief object of criticism by his Democratic rivals. Yesterday, aides to Senator John Edwards of North Carolina and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri circulated a newspaper article highlighting Dr. Dean's comment that a "white male president can talk to whites about racism, and a white male president can talk to men about domestic violence better than a woman who is a victim."
Tricia Enright, Dr. Dean's communications director, noted that he had made that remark during a meeting of women's advocates, and said of the Edwards-Gephardt tactic, "I don't know whether this is more offensive or pathetic."
"He's saying, you know, race is a white person's problem, too, and domestic violence is a man's problem, too," she said. "What he's saying is you have a responsibility as president to use the bully pulpit to talk about these issues, as tough and difficult as they are."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Howard Dean tossed a Red Sox cap back to its owner yesterday as he took his presidential campaign to Copley Square in Boston. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.N. Official Plans to Urge U.S. to Reconsider Its Food Policies 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Jacques Diouf, the director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, dedicated to helping solve the world's hunger problems, knows he has a hard sell on Capitol Hill.
 Mr. Diouf is here on a visit from his Rome headquarters, trying to keep alive the issues that stalled trade talks in Cancun, Mexico, last week. Like many at the talks, he wants Congress and the administration to reconsider the nation's annual $22 billion in farm subsidies, which make it hard for farmers in poorer countries to compete. 
 But he also wants to make a separate, difficult point: that the United States' generosity with food aid sometimes undermines countries' abilities to feed themselves.
The United States provides 41 percent of the food aid distributed by the United Nations. But in an interview at his agency's Washington offices, Mr. Diouf said hunger could be better fought if money were spent to help poor farmers dig wells and canals for irrigation and lay better roads to bring crops to market. 
"Giving money to farmers before a crisis is better than giving food after the crisis hits," he said.
In the last 15 years, as rich countries increased their subsidies to their farmers and slashed aid to the world's poorest farmers, poor countries have gone from net exporters of food to net importers. With 70 percent of poor countries' populations dependent on agriculture for their livelihoods, the change has helped fuel a rise in malnutrition. In places like sub-Saharan Africa, one out of three people suffer chronic hunger.
Mr. Diouf will meet with officials including Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee; Andrew S. Natsios, administrator of the United States Agency for International Development; and Ann M. Veneman, secretary of agriculture.
But there is no immediate legislation before Congress, and both Republican and Democratic politicians are publicly rejecting much of the criticism leveled at the United States by the developing nations at Cancun. With the 2004 election on their minds, many lawmakers said they were disinclined to question the subsidies.
Mr. Diouf, an agricultural economist, said he would remind the lawmakers of the cold war era, when presidents like Ronald Reagan spent as much as $1.3 billion every year to help farmers around the world. Today, the United States gives some $400 million to that effort.
But the resistance to his various messages may be high. At a Congressional hearing today, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said he saw a bigger problem in tariffs imposed on imports by some poor countries, which make the exports of other poor countries less affordable.
"The vast bulk of market access barriers faced by farmers in developing countries are imposed by other developing countries," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
As More Markets Go Public, Salaries Are Under Scrutiny

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
By the standards of the New York Stock Exchange, James J. McNulty, the president and chief executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, does not have an outsized salary. It was slightly less than $1.9 million last year.
 But when his stock options are added, his total potential compensation is many times larger. 
 At yesterday's closing price of $70.25, his exercisable options on the shares of Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, which recently went public, were worth $69 million. Add the options he holds that cannot be exercised yet and the total value climbs to $86 million. 
Mr. McNulty's options, granted when he was hired in February 2000, indicate the potential for individual profit at other exchanges that are moving toward going public or considering the possibility, as the New York Stock Exchange is.
The question is whether other exchanges, which perform regulatory functions like trading oversight and arbitration, can be as generous as the Mercantile Exchange, given the scrutiny generated by the compensation furor at the Big Board.
Some new focus may also fall on the American Stock Exchange. An official who has seen some details of the compensation for Salvatore Sodano, its chairman and chief executive, said late last night that Mr. Sodano was paid about $5 million last year. His package includes a pension, deferred compensation and a severance agreement that totals about $22 million.
One exchange that is taking steps toward going public, the Chicago Board of Trade, appears so far to have decided not to give its top five executives stock options or shares in the proposed public company, judging by the most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The current top executive's pay is actually a little bit less than the No. 2 executive's, and only half that of his predecessor, whose contract also entitles him to stock in the C.B.O.T. if it goes public.
Constantine Papadakis, chairman of the compensation committee at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and president of Drexel University, said that he thought this was a "new era" for stock options.
"I don't object, but at the same time I have to be convinced that we add value," he said when asked about granting options to the Philadelphia exchange's top executives. The Philadelphia exchange is planning to go public.
Paul Hodgson, senior research associate for the Corporate Library, said he did not think other exchanges would be able to match the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. "The Mercantile Exchange has put the spotlight on them now," he said, "so they won't be able to slip it through."
Outside of the Big Board and the American Stock Exchange, base salary levels do not seem to be a major issue. But not all of the exchanges have disclosed the compensation of their executives in the past.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which trades futures contracts on interest rates, indexes, currencies and commodities, must disclose executive pay now that it is public. The Chicago Board of Trade, also a futures exchange, has begun disclosure before going public.
Meyer S. Frucher, chairman and chief operating officer of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, which trades stocks and equity, index and currency options, disclosed his compensation when asked by a reporter.
The Chicago Board Options Exchange, which trades options on stocks and stock indexes, declined to release compensation data; so did the International Securities Exchange, which trades options electronically. The Pacific Stock Exchange, which trades options on stocks, had not provided compensation information by late yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange was in the process of arranging the regular disclosure of compensation as the information on Mr. Sodano's compensation surfaced. The exchange's place in the market, which is closer to that of the other exchanges than the Big Board, may add to criticism on the compensation. Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the Big Board had total compensation of $12 million in 2002, after a $30.6 million payout in 2001. Mr. Grasso resigned after his $139.5 million deferred-compensation package drew heavy criticism.
Mr. Frucher of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange was paid a salary of $600,000 in 2002, the same as his predecessor. Healso received a $300,000 bonus, the largest of his tenure so far. In addition, the board gave him a $600,000 loan, which is being forgiven at $200,000 a year in an effort to retain him, Mr. Papadakis, the compensation committee chairman, said.
"After he has read all the news about Grasso, he will probably ask for a raise," Mr. Papadakis joked. 
Bernard W. Dan, president and chief executive of Chicago Board of Trade Holdings, was paid a salary of $422,051 in 2002, with a bonus and other compensation that brought his total to $891,121. The executive vice president and chief of staff, Carol A. Burke, got total compensation of $908,788. Mr. Dan's predecessor, David J. Vitale, was paid $1,779,459 in salary and bonus in 2001, according to regulatory filings; the value of the stock he is entitled to receive in a publicly owned C.B.O.T. will not be known until the exchange gets to the point of actually going public.
One reason for the difference is that Mr. Vitale had been recruited from outside the exchange, while Mr. Dan was promoted from within.
Mr. McNulty, who is leaving the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at the end of the year, declined to comment through a spokeswoman. She did note that the market value of the exchange had jumped to $3.1 billion from $900 million during his tenure.
Four other top executives at the exchange also hold options, now worth a total of $7 million each, with $2.8 million of that exercisable now, according to regulatory filings.
"Giving that many options to Mr. McNulty is a board problem," said Scott C. Newquist, president of Board Governance Services. "It is up to the board to explain what incremental value the exchange is getting by paying McNulty $50 million instead of $10 million."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Procter & Gamble bets that men will buy a car wash called Mr. Clean.

BYLINE:  By Claudia Deutsch 

 BODY:
WILL macho guys use their mamas' Mr. Clean to wash their muscle cars?
 Procter & Gamble sure hopes so. The consumer products powerhouse is no longer content to bolster Mr. Clean, the 45-year-old brand of liquid cleanser, with garden-variety extensions like new scents and wipes, nor with simply licensing the name for merchandise like gloves and mops sold by other companies. 
 For the first time in decades, Procter is putting the bald character's imprimatur on new Mr. Clean products of its own: Mr. Clean Magic Eraser, for removing crayon marks from walls and scuff marks from chair rails, and Mr. Clean Autodry, for leaving a freshly washed car spot-free without hand drying.
The brand-product connection for Magic Eraser is easy to spot: Mr. Clean has always sold mainly to women, and that is the market Magic Eraser is chasing.
But cars? Cars driven by men? Men described by Marc Stoiber, executive creative director at the Toronto office of Grey Worldwide Canada, the unit of the Grey Global Group that is developing both campaigns, as "the Nascar crowd, who love drag races and chrome and squealing tires and hoods they can see their reflection in"? 
You may think that conventional wisdom would say no, but Robert D. Gilbreath, brand manager for Mr. Clean North America at Procter in Cincinnati, insists that the research dictates yes.
"We tested made-up names, we tested Dawn, and in every test, guys said that Mr. Clean was the name they'd trust most," Mr. Gilbreath said. Dawn, a Procter dishwashing liquid, is already used by many people to wash cars. 
Mr. Stoiber said he thought he knew the secret: "Mr. Clean may be smiling and approachable, but come on, look at the muscles on that guy."
Procter is certainly putting marketing muscle behind Mr. Clean, with a marketing budget triple that of last year, when it spent $24.3 million to advertise the brand in major media, according to the TNS Media Intelligence/CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres. 
Analysts are not surprised by the higher spending. "Mr. Clean isn't a mission-critical brand for a $48 billion company like Procter, but its name and image resonates with consumers," said William H. Steele, an analyst with Banc of America Securities. "It's a real opportunity brand, one that has legs."
The new push for Mr. Clean is a logical outgrowth of a Procter effort to slough off brands that have little prospect for growth, and focus attention on the rest, particularly those with sales exceeding $1 billion a year, like Crest, Pampers and Tide.
Procter sold Comet and Spic and Span, two profitable but aging cleaning products that "we just didn't think we could take farther," Mr. Gilbreath said. It introduced Swiffer, a hybrid broom-mop that cleans floors with disposable wipes, and for a time the company considered using that brand on Autodry. But research showed that, unlike Swiffer, Mr. Clean was more than a brand. "He's an icon," Mr. Gilbreath said, "and we'd underestimated his power."
The new products have vastly different roots. Magic Eraser is Procter's version of a cleaning product that some company executives saw in use in Japan. (Alan S. Goldstein, manager of research and development for Mr. Clean, said there were no patent infringement issues.) 
Procter seems convinced that acceptance will be easy, and its marketing, based around the theme "It's magic," is almost minimalist. There will be six $1-off coupons in newspaper inserts. A print ad meant to resemble an old-time magic-show poster is headlined, "And for my next trick I'll make this mark disappear."
A television commercial, to start running next Wednesday, shows a frustrated mother trying to rub crayon stains off a wall. Mr. Clean materializes next to her, demonstrates how easily Magic Eraser does the job -- and watches her mark the wall with crayon, just so she can rub it off again.
Suggested prices for Magic Eraser, which is already in stores, are $2.19 for a package of two and $4.19 for four. Procter expects $30 million to $40 million in sales in its first full year, Mr. Gilbreath said.
Autodry, a homegrown product that took more than three years to develop, will pull in $100 million in its first year, Mr. Gilbreath predicted. Not surprisingly, Procter is putting a lot more effort and money behind it.
The product attaches to a garden hose and uses special soaps and filters to keep water from beading on car surfaces. A starter kit, good for about three washes, is intended to retail for about $19.99. Soap and filter refills will go for $4.99 each.
Mr. Gilbreath conceded that all auto-wash products claim to leave no spots, so he said he turned to colleagues at Procter's Old Spice division to find out how to dispel healthy male skepticism. The Old Spice answer: endorsements, guarantees, race cars and technology.
Autodry's marketing stresses those points. The product package includes the logo of Pur, Procter's brand of water filter, as well as a "Motor Trend approved" logo -- the automotive equivalent of a Good Housekeeping seal. Procter is offering a one-year money-back guarantee.
Although Autodry will not be shipped to retailers until January, Procter is already running 60-second and 120-second spots on CMT (Country Music Television) and ESPN, which include a toll-free telephone number for orders. Procter is sponsoring a Mr. Clean Autodry race car, to be driven by Wally Dallenbach, a retired Nascar driver turned NBC racing sportscaster.. 
Mr. Clean Autodry is one of eight Procter brands competing for the commercial time the company has bought during Super Bowl XXXVIII on Jan. 25, the trade publication Ad Age reported this week. Also, an Autodry commercial will probably run in conjunction with the Busch Series Nascar race at Daytona Speedway, held the day before the Daytona 500 in February.
The full campaign, to start running in March, will include print ads in magazines as well as TV ads. "Our target is the car aficionado and gadget lover, and we figure the message will trickle down from them to the average dads who wash their car," Mr. Stoiber said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Remains Leader in Global Arms Sales, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The United States maintained its dominance in the international arms market last year, especially in sales to developing nations, according to a new Congressional report.
 The United States was the leader in total worldwide sales in 2002, with about $13.3 billion, or 45.5 percent of global conventional weapons deals, a rise from $12.1 billion in 2001. Of that, $8.6 billion was to developing nations, or about 48.6 percent of conventional arms deals concluded with developing nations last year, according to the report. 
 Russia was second in sales to the developing world last year, with $5 billion, followed by France with $1 billion. 
While the report focuses on sales and deliveries of conventional weapons from the industrialized world to poorer nations, it also offers a glimpse into such issues as missile proliferation by North Korea and foreign weapons transfers to Iraq.
The new report, "Conventional Arms Transfers to Developing Nations, 1995-2002," was sent to the House and Senate this week by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress. The annual study, written by Richard F. Grimmett, a specialist in national defense at the research service, is considered the most authoritative resource available to the public on worldwide weapons sales.
From 1999 to 2002, there were no deliveries of surface-to-surface missiles to the Middle East from arms makers in the United States, Russia, China or Europe, the report said.
But the study says 60 surface-to-surface missiles were delivered to the Middle East by nations in the category "All Others," which includes such suppliers as Israel, South Africa and North Korea.
United States officials, both military and civilian, said today that North Korea was the source of the surface-to-surface missile deliveries listed in the report, and of 10 anti-ship missiles delivered to the Middle East in that period.
President Bush has increased public pressure on North Korea and Iran over their nuclear programs, and the administration is organizing a number of joint military exercises to train for the interdiction of possible shipments. The goal of these exercises is to make it more difficult to transmit components of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons -- and the missiles to deliver them.
But difficulties in halting North Korea's missile trade were evident in December, when a North Korean cargo vessel that was not flying a flag was halted off the Horn of Africa by two Spanish warships.
A search revealed 15 Scud missiles hidden beneath the cargo. But the vessel was eventually allowed to sail on with the missiles to its destination in Yemen after officials conceded that neither North Korea nor Yemen had violated any treaties.
In addition to the shipment to Yemen, North Korea is suspected of selling missile technology to Iran and others, Pentagon officials said.
The study says that none of the major arms makers delivered weapons to Iraq from 1999 to 2002 -- or at least not in amounts of more than $50 million, the lowest sales amount included in the study.
But a category of nations labeled "All Other European," which includes formerly Communist states in Central and Eastern Europe, delivered about $100 million worth of weapons to Iraq from 1999 to 2002, although the report does not specify the source of the deliveries.
Ukraine is believed by American officials to have sold an advanced Kolchuga radar system to Iraq, Pentagon officials said.
Arms deals with developing nations in 2002 totaled $17.7 billion, more than the $16.2 billion for 2001 but the second-lowest total for the years 1995 to 2002. (The report measures sales and deliveries in dollar totals adjusted for inflation, called "constant 2002 dollars.")
"Many developing nations have curtailed their expenditures on weaponry primarily due to their limited financial resources," Mr. Grimmett wrote in the report. "To meet their military requirements, in current circumstances, a number of developing nations have placed a greater emphasis on upgrading existing weapons systems while deferring purchases of new and costlier ones."
Total arms transfer agreements reached nearly $29.2 billion in 2002, a decrease from 2001 and the second year in a row that total arms sales dropped, according to the study.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: ALLIES; 
Mongolians Return to Baghdad, This Time as Peacekeepers

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, Sept. 22 

 BODY:
In 1258, the Mongol general Hulegu, a grandson of Genghis Khan, sacked Baghdad, killing 800,000 people and ending its primacy as the largest city in the Arab world.
 This month, the Mongolians returned to Iraq. Ferried into the country on American military transports, 180 Mongolian Army soldiers -- all male, all volunteers -- are guarding pipelines and working on construction projects under a Polish command. 
 "This is not like the 13th century," Col. B. Erkhenbayar, commander of Mongolia's Peacekeeping Operation Battalion, said here, smiling so widely his eyes disappeared. "Then, we went to invade. This time, we are going to build Iraq." 
In the Bush administration's roster of 34 nations serving in Iraq in the American-led "coalition of the willing" about half are formerly Communist countries like Mongolia. Like many other normally overlooked nations that have sent soldiers to Iraq, Mongolia did so more out of geopolitics than concern for Iraq. Mongolia's offer of troops surprised the American government because it had not asked Mongolia for help, said Steven R. Saunders, president of a private, Washington-based group promoting business ties with Mongolia.
Around this dusty city with its Cyrillic character signs left over from the Soviet era, Mongolians talk of supporting democracy in Iraq, of bolstering geopolitical ties with the United States and of returning their nation's long-eclipsed name to the world stage.
Mongolia is the only nation in Northeast Asia where there is widespread support for sending troops to Iraq: Russia glowers, China appears neutral and Japan has approved the sending of troops but begs for more time. South Korea has 650 military medics and engineers in Iraq, sent despite violent public protests. Now, in the face of American demands for combat-trained troops, South Korea is sending a study group.
Slightly more than a decade after the departure of the last Soviet troops here, democracy is not an abstraction for Mongolia. Last summer, Tibetan Buddhist priests working at a monastery here disinterred the remains of about 600 lamas, or high priests, each buried with his hands tied behind his back and a bullet hole in the skull. They were killed in 1937 by Mongolian Communists in an effort by Stalin to stamp out Mongolia's historic religion.
"Words are not enough to fight with terrorism," Prime Minister Nambaryn Enkhbayar of Mongolia said in an interview last week, fresh from welcoming delegates from 118 countries classified as new or restored democracies.
Mongolia is rapidly embracing the United States in an effort to develop a balance to its historically dangerous neighbors, China and Russia. Twice the size of Texas, but with only 2.4 million people, this land of nomadic herders has a deep, if rarely voiced, fear of becoming another Tibet. After centuries of Chinese rule, Mongolia won independence only in 1921 with Soviet support.
Gen. T. Togoo, chief of staff of the Mongolian armed forces, noted that, historically, Mongolia won breathing space by pitting neighbors against each other. As he spoke, rap music from the Voice of America radio filtered through his Soviet-built headquarters.
At the training ground for the peacekeeping unit, the rear window of a Soviet-made jeep carried two fresh stickers in red and gold: "Semper Fi" and "USMC," souvenirs from 50 United States marines who left last week after leading a training exercise.
"Even though our country is locked between China and Russia, the biggest countries in the world, we should not restrict our relations," Colonel Erkhenbayar said in his second- floor office, decorated with photos, patches, and medals from nearly a decade of contacts with American military forces. "America could be our first neighbor, the way it is for Poland."
The Mongolian efforts appear to be paying dividends. "They were one of the first nations to sign up to send peacekeepers to Iraq," Pamela J. H. Slutz, the American ambassador here, said in an interview. "That has created enormous good will in Washington. For us it was also a prime example of the utility and success of our military assistance program."
The United States has provided the Mongolian military with peacekeeping training, English lessons and, for the Chinese border area, patrol radios and engineering work.
According to foreign mining company employees who work in the Gobi Desert border areas, this "engineering work" seems to involve installing electronic surveillance equipment to monitor North Korea and the Lop Nor nuclear testing site in China, which is just across Mongolia's western border.
American Embassy officials here declined to comment on these reports.
In addition, the United States is advising Mongolia on how to reshape its military for the post-Soviet era. Over the last 20 years, Mongolia's military has shrunk by two-thirds, to about 15,000 today. Last year, a law took effect defining the military's primary missions as border patrol, disaster relief and participation in international peacekeeping missions.
By sending troops to Iraq, Mongolia hopes to win powerful friends for a small nation that is often confused with Inner Mongolia, the neighboring Chinese province.
"Now," said Col. Gurin Ragchaa, a military spokesman, "everyone will know where Mongolia is."
"We are squeezed between two superpowers, so having an army is not enough," Prime Minister Enkhbayar said in English honed at the London School of Economics and Americanized in trips to Washington. "We have to secure our sovereignty and independence through diplomatic measures, economic measures, international organizations."
Two weeks ago, as the last Mongolian soldiers arrived in Iraq, Mongolia, whose trade with the United States was only $180 million last year, formally proposed to Washington a free trade pact.
"Negotiations could be concluded in one weekend," Mr. Saunders said over a pineapple pizza lunch at the California Restaurant, one of the latest American cultural imitations here. "It would have not any economic impact on the U.S. In one year, the U.S. trades less with Mongolia than what it trades with Taiwan in 12 hours."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 9, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 25 about the arrival of Mongolian peacekeeping troops on American transports to serve in Iraq misstated the number of people killed by the armies of the general Hulegu in a past Mongol operation -- the sacking of Baghdad in 1258. Historians generally agree that it was 80,000, not 800,000.
